Description: THE GOAL OF OUR PROJECT IS TO EVALUATE HOW NOVEL REGENERATIVE ORGANIC HORTICULTURAL PRACTICES AFFECT SOIL HEALTH, INSECT AND DISEASE INCIDENCE, WEED OCCURRENCE, AND CROP YIELD OF COMMON CENTRAL COAST VEGETABLES. OUR PROJECT IS INSPIRED BY TEST FIELDS ESTABLISHED BY BRAGA FRESH IN THE SALINAS VALLEY EXPLORING A BEDLESS VEGETABLE PRODUCTION SYSTEM THAT MAINTAINS BOTH A RYE AND CLOVER COVER CROP ALONG WITH A TRANSPLANTED CASH CROP. MEMBERS OF THE BRAGA FRESH TEAM HAVE INDICATED A FOUR TO FIVE FOLD REDUCTION IN TRACTOR PASSES ON THEIR TEST PLOTS COMPARED TO THEIR STANDARD SHAPED BED PRODUCTION SYSTEMS WITH LOW YIELD REDUCTIONS(KYLE HARMON, PERSONAL COMMUNICATION). WORKING IN COLLABORATION WITH BRAGA FRESH, WE SEEK TO CONDUCT A REPLICATED MULTI-YEAR STUDY THAT CAN EXPAND ON THEIR PRELIMINARY RESULTS, WHILE DEVELOPING UNIQUE FIELD-BASED LEARNING MODULES THAT WILL PROVIDE CAL POLY STUDENTS WITH OPPORTUNITIES TO EXPAND THEIR KNOWLEDGE OF ORGANIC PRODUCTION SYSTEMS, SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION PRACTICES, EXPERIMENTAL LOGIC, DESIGN, ANALYSIS AND REPORTING, AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF OUTREACH MATERIALS. TO THIS END, WE PLAN TO:DEVELOP A CONTROLLED, MULTI-YEAR FIELD TRIAL COMPARING STANDARD ORGANIC PRACTICE TO ALTERNATIVE REGENERATIVE SYSTEMS;DETERMINE HOW REGENERATIVE PRACTICES AFFECT YIELD AND INSECT, DISEASE AND WEED PRESSURE INCLUDING ASSESSMENT OF POTENTIAL SYNERGIES AND TRADEOFFS COMPARED WITH STANDARD ORGANIC SYSTEM,DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL MODULES FOR CAL POLY SLO STUDENTS INTEGRATED WITH LONG-TERM MONITORING PROTOCOLS AND SCIENCE COMMUNICATION ,EXTEND PROJECT OUTCOMES TO CENTRAL COAST ORGANIC FARMERS.THE PROJECT IS INTENDED AS A PROOF-OF-CONCEPT EXPLORING DISRUPTIVE TECHNOLOGIES FOR THE FUTURE OF ORGANIC VEGETABLE PRODUCTION IN THE CENTRAL COAST REGION. EXTENSIVE EVALUATION AND OPTIMIZATION WILL BE NEEDED TO MAKE THE PROPOSED SYSTEMS SCALABLE. CAL POLY SLO AND THE GRIMM FAMILY CENTER FOR ORGANIC PRODUCTION AND RESEARCH ARE UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO CONDUCT THIS RESEARCH, GIVEN ITS LOCATION IN THE CENTRAL COAST REGION, ACCESS TO LAND FOR FIELD TRIALS, AND ABILITY TO BREAK DOWN SILOS AND WORK IN INTERDISCIPLINARY TEAMS INCLUDING SOIL SCIENTISTS, ENTOMOLOGISTS, PLANT PATHOLOGISTS, AND AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERS. THE PROPOSED RESEARCH IS AIMED TO BE THE BEGINNING OF A LONG-TERM TRIAL, CREATING OPPORTUNITIES TO STUDY VARIOUS ASPECTS OF THESE NOVEL AND DIVERSE LOW-TILL ORGANIC VEGETABLE CROPPING SYSTEMS. PROVIDING HANDS ON TRAINING FOR CAL POLY STUDENTS IS AN EQUALLY IMPORTANT OUTCOME FOR THIS PROJECT AS IT WILL DEVELOP THE TALENT NEEDED TO FURTHER DEVELOP ORGANIC PRODUCTION IN THE CENTRAL COAST AND BEYOND.

THE AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS PROGRAM AT TXST IS IN DESPERATE NEED OF NEW EQUIPMENT IN THE MACHINERY MANAGEMENT LABORATORY. WITHIN THE MACHINERY MANAGEMENT COURSE AT TXST, STUDENTS ASSIGNED INTO TEAMS, ARE ASSIGNED A SEMESTER LONG PROJECT THAT MUST BE COMPLETED BY THE END OF THE SEMESTER. THESE PROJECTS INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO TRACTOR OR FARM IMPLEMENT RESTORATION, REFURBISHMENT, AND ENGINE REBUILDS. THROUGH THIS PROPOSAL, STUDENTS IN COURSES WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO WORK WITH MODERN INDUSTRY STANDARD EQUIPMENT TO COMPLETE THESE PROJECTS. THE PURCHASE OF THE NEW EQUIPMENT ALLOWS STUDENTS TO DEVELOP TRADITIONAL TECHNICAL SKILLS, BUT ALSO COMMUNICATION AND TEAMWORK OR SOFT SKILLS. SOFT SKILLS ARE IDENTIFIED AS KEY COMPETENCIES THAT EMPLOYERS LOOK TO FOR IN NEW HIRES. THIS PROJECT IMPROVES THE MACHINERY MANAGEMENT EQUIPMENT THROUGH THE PURCHASE OF SEVEN SNAP-ON PREMIUM COMBINATION TOOL SETS, AS WELL AS, FLOOR JACKS, JACK STANDS, ENGINE HOISTS, ENGINE STANDS, PARTS CLEANERS, SAND BLASTERS, A SAND BLASTING CABINET, PALM SANDERS, AND IMPACT WRENCHES AND SOCKET SETS. THIS EDUCATION PROJECT TYPE PROPOSAL ALIGNS WITH THE AGRICULTURAL/BIOLOGICAL ENGINEERING DISCIPLINE (CODE E). THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO IMPROVE STUDENTS' EXPERIENCE IN THE MACHINERY MANAGEMENT LABORATORY AREA FOR DAS STUDENTS AT TXST. THE PURPOSE WILL BE FULFILLED BY THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: 1) PROVIDE A LEARNING ENVIRONMENT THAT EDUCATES STUDENTS UTILIZING INDUSTRY-STANDARD EQUIPMENT IN THE MACHINERY MANAGEMENT LABORATORY SPACE.; 2) INCREASE STUDENT ENGAGEMENT WITHIN AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS MAJOR AND COURSES AT TXST.; 3) HOST PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS FOR SBAE TEACHERS INTERESTED IN MACHINERY MANAGEMENT AND EQUIPMENT REFURBISHMENT.

AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION IN SOUTH FLORIDA IS INCREASINGLY COMING UNDER PRESSURE DUE TO INCREASED FLOODING, SALTWATER INTRUSION, AND SOIL EROSION.THE AGRICULTURAL CHALLENGES ARE INTENSIFIED WITH THE PROJECTED SEA LEVEL RISE OF ONE FOOT IN NEXT 30 YEARS IN FLORIDA. WITH INCREASING EXTREME CLIMATE EVENTS LEADING TO AGRICULTURE LOSSES, WELL-INFORMED ADJUSTMENTS TO CROP PRODUCTION ARE NEEDED TO FEED A GROWING POPULATION WITHOUT HARMING THE ENVIRONMENT.THIS PROPOSAL IS A SYNERGY BETWEEN STUDENT TRAINING, EXTENSION EFFORTS, RESEARCH AND OUTREACH TO AGRICULTURE PRODUCERS INTERESTED IN APPLIED FIELD RESEARCH ON SOIL QUALITY AND CROP MONITORING USING ACQUIRED FIELD INSTRUMENTATION FOR MONITORING CROP HEALTH (MULTISPECTRAL DRONE) AND SOIL HEALTH (FTIR-MIR SPECTROMETER).THESE PORTABLE INSTRUMENTS WILL ALSO ALLOW INSTRUCTORS TO CONDUCT FIELD-LABORATORY EXERCISES, AND EXTENSION TRAINING IN THE AREA OF PLANT-SOIL INTERFACE WITH APPLICATIONS IN CROP MANAGEMENT, AND SOIL HEALTH. THE PROPOSED INTEGRATEDPROJECT WILL IMPACT ATLEAST 100 STUDENTS BY IMPROVING THEIR TECHNICAL AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS THROUGH IMPROVED CURRICULUM, ACTIVE LEARNING AND SUMMER RESEARCH INTERNSHIP FOR 6 STUDENTS IN AGRICULTURE DISCIPLINE. THE PROGRAM HAS THE POTENTIAL TO YIELD SIGNIFICANT OUTCOMES IN MINORITY STUDENT GRADUATION, LEADERSHIP AND EMPLOYABILITY.

DAIRY FARMS ARE INCREASINGLY BECOMING MORE CONSOLIDATED, WHILE SMALL FAMILY FARMS ARE RAPIDLY DECLINING. EACH YEAR WISCONSIN LOSES SEVERAL HUNDRED FAMILY FARMS. THESE CHANGES UNDOUBTABLY HAVE AN IMPACT ON THE SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC CONDITIONS IN RURAL COMMUNITIES, AFFECTING SOCIAL AND MENTAL WELL-BEING OF INDIVIDUALS. FOR EXAMPLE, CONCERNS ABOUT MENTAL HEALTH AND INCREASED SUICIDE OCCURRENCE FROM AGRICULTURAL AND RURAL COMMUNITIES HAVE BEEN REPORTED. WITH A NEED TO INCREASE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION BY 50% UNTIL THE YEAR 2050, WE NEED TO ENSURE OUR PRODUCTION SYSTEMS ARE RESILIENT IN ALL ASPECTS OF THE SOCIO-ECONOMIC SYSTEM, REQUIRING MULTIDISCIPLINARY APPROACHES THAT ADDRESS WHICH FACTORS CONTRIBUTE TO RESILIENT ECOSYSTEMS, GREATER COMMUNITY WELFARE, INCLUDING MENTAL HEALTH, AS WELL AS IMPROVED ANIMAL WELFARE, AND THUS ECONOMIC SUSTAINABILITY. IF WE RECOGNIZE THAT SUSTAINABILITY IS MORE THAN JUST PROTECTING THE ENVIRONMENT, WE CAN RECOGNIZE THAT FOSTERING SUSTAINABILITY IN THE DAIRY INDUSTRY MEANS ENSURING ECONOMIC VIABILITY FOR DAIRY FARMERS, AS WELL AS MENTAL AND PHYSICAL WELL-BEING. GIVEN THE SENSITIVITY AROUND MANY OF THESE ISSUES, ESTABLISHING GOOD RELATIONSHIPS WITH FARMERS IS VITAL.SUPPORT FROM THIS GRANT ALLOWS FOR FOUNDATIONAL OUTREACH TO ESTABLISH CONTACTS AND BUILD TRUST BETWEEN FARMERS AND RESEARCHERS, ALLOWING FOR MORE ROBUST AND HONEST DISCUSSIONS AND SHARING OF INFORMATION. THIS PLANNING GRANT WILL GATHER DAIRY FARMERS FROM GRAZING AND CONFINEMENT DAIRY SYSTEMS, STAKEHOLDER GROUPS, INCLUDING COMMUNITY LEADERS FROM AROUND THE UW RIVER FALLS AND PLATTEVILLE CAMPUSES, TO ASSESS HOW DIFFERENT ASPECTS OF FARM MANAGEMENT AFFECT THE THREE PILLARS OF THE ONE HEALTH/WELFARE APPROACH, WHICH INCLUDE HUMAN, ANIMAL, AND ECOSYSTEM HEALTH.IN COLLABORATION WITH THE DAIRY PRODUCERS, WE WILL REFINE THE EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN AND METHODS FOR A FULL RESEARCH PROPOSAL, TO ACCOMMODATE FARM MANAGEMENT AND TO MINIMIZE INTERFERENCE WITH FARM OPERATIONS. AS PART OF THE OUTCOMES, WE WILL IDENTIFY FARMS THAT WILL SERVE AS EXPERIMENTAL LOCATIONS TO EVALUATE THE ONE HEALTH/WELFARE APPROACH WITHIN GRAZING AND CONFINEMENT DAIRY SYSTEMS FOR A FULL RESEARCH PROPOSAL. PRIOR TO THE MEETINGS WE WILL REACH OUT TO SEVERAL PRODUCERS BY PHONE AND EMAIL, INCLUDING BRIEF SURVEYS TO GAUGE THEIR INTERESTS IN SUCH MEETINGS. PRODUCTS FROM THIS PLANNING GRANT WILL ALSO INCLUDE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR SCIENCE-PRODUCER COLLABORATIONS, AS WELL AS FARMER COMPENSATION FOR ON-FARM PARTICIPATORY RESEARCH.

AN INCREASING NUMBER OF NEW SMALL AND MEDIUM-SIZE FARM OPERATORS IN THE U.S. SEEK SELF-REPRESENTATION, EFFICIENT MARKETING, AND DIGITAL MARKETING. MANY OF THE NEW/SMALL FARM OPERATORS HAVE LIMITED PREVIOUS KNOWLEDGE OF THIS KIND. UNFORTUNATELY, UNIVERSITIES HAVE NOT KEPT PACE WITH THE INCREASING DEMAND FROM PRODUCERS FOR THIS TYPE OF EDUCATIONAL DEGREE AND ASSOCIATED OUTREACH AND RESEARCH. A STANDARDIZED PROGRAM THAT COVERS THESE TOPICS AND DELIVERS THE INFORMATION CONVENIENTLY TO THESE PRODUCERS IS NEEDED. IN THIS PROJECT, WE PROPOSE TO CREATE AN AGRICULTURAL DIGITAL MARKETING LEARNING SYSTEM TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF DIGITAL MARKETING, ENHANCE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF DATA-ORIENTED MARKETING APPROACHES, AND PROMOTE SELF-REPRESENTATION PRACTICES FOR TEXAS AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR ONGOING, SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT THAT WILL ADDRESS STAKEHOLDER NEEDS AND THE LONG-TERM GOALS OF BUILDING ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT CAPACITY IN SYSTEMS-BASED DIGITAL MARKETING IN AGRICULTURE. THIS APPLICATION IS AN INTEGRATED PROPOSAL THAT WILL CREATE PROJECTS TO STRENGTHEN HIGHER EDUCATION TEACHING PROGRAMS IN FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES (DISCIPLINE: M). THESE PROJECTS WILL ASSIST THE SHSU SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES TO EXPAND ITS CAPACITY TO CONDUCT EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH/EXTENSION ACTIVITIES BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO LEARN ABOUT DIGITAL MARKETING IN AGRICULTURE. THE PROJECTS WILL EMPLOY GRADUATE STUDENTS. TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS ENTERING FOOD AND AGRICULTURE-RELATED DISCIPLINES, WE WILL WORK WITH THE MINORITIES IN AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, AND RELATED SCIENCES (MANRRS) STUDENT ORGANIZATION AT SHSU. THIS PROPOSAL ALIGNS WITH NLGCA AND USDA'S STRATEGIC GOAL TO FACILITATE RURAL PROSPERITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT.

STRENGTHENING SUSTAINABLE FOOD PRODUCTION AND ENHANCING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTIVITY CAN PROVIDE SOLUTIONS TO OVERCOME GLOBAL HUNGER. THE SECOND SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT GOAL OF THE UNITED NATIONS HIGHLIGHTS THE NEED FOR PROMOTING SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE BY EMPOWERING SMALL FARMERS (UN SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT GOALS, 2021). THE UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE MARTIN AND PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIVERSITY WILL COLLABORATE ON THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT TO BUILD REGIONAL CAPACITY FOR AGRICULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY BY INVOLVING SMALLHOLDER FORAGE-LIVESTOCK AND VEGETABLE FARMERS IN RESEARCH, EDUCATION, PRODUCER EXCHANGE SCHOOLS, AND A REGIONAL SUSTAINABILITY CONFERENCE (C, P, S CODES). STUDENT INTERNSHIPS FOR RESEARCH AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING WILL BE CREATED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH SECONDARY EDUCATORS, AND FARMERS' MARKETS AND LOCAL FOOD NETWORKS WILL BE HIGHLIGHTED AS INSTRUMENTS FOR FOOD SELF-SUFFICIENCY. ANOTHER GOAL IS TO PROMOTE GLOBAL ENGAGEMENT AND CULTURAL AWARENESS AMONG STUDENTS THROUGH AN EMBEDDED COURSE INCLUDING AN INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL STUDY PROGRAM (CODE I) ON SUSTAINABILITY PRACTICES IN INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES.RESEARCH PROJECTS FOCUS ON SUSTAINABLE FORAGE AND VEGETABLE PRODUCTION SYSTEMS THAT ADDRESS THE NEED AREA OF APPLIED STUDIES IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. EDUCATIONAL PROJECTS ADDRESS NEED AREAS SUCH AS CURRICULUM DESIGN, COLLABORATIVE INTERACTION WITH OTHER ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS, INSTRUCTION DELIVERY SYSTEMS AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING. OUTREACH PROJECTS ADDRESS NEED AREAS SUCH AS NATURAL RESOURCES, FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES, AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT. THE PROJECT WILL: EQUIP SMALLHOLDER FARMERS WITH SUSTAINABLE METHODS OF FORAGE AND VEGETABLE PRODUCTION; ENHANCE AWARENESS OF STUDENTS ON GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES OF SUSTAINABILITY; PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FACULTY TO IMPROVE RESEARCH, TEACHING AND MENTORING SKILLS AND; HIGHLIGHT THE IMPORTANCE OF FARMERS' MARKETS AND LOCAL FOOD NETWORKS.

THE PROPOSED RESEARCH PROJECT ADDRESSES THE TARGETED NEED AREA OF APPLIED STUDIES IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. FIRST, THE LONG-TERM RESEARCH GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO INCREASE CROP PRODUCTION THROUGH THE MANIPULATION OF CROP GENOMICS, GENETIC RESOURCES, AND BIOTECHNOLOGY. PHYTOPHTHORA STEM AND ROOT ROT (PSR) IS CAUSED BY THE OOMYCETEPHYTOPHTHORA SOJAEAND LEADS TO SIGNIFICANT SOYBEAN LOSSES. THE DISEASE IS CURRENTLY MANAGED BY DEPLOYING RESISTANT SOYBEAN CULTIVARS CARRYINGRPS(RESISTANCEPHYTOPHTHORA. SOJAE) GENES/ALLELES.UPON RECOGNITION OF THE PATHOGEN, RPS PROTEINS INITIATE A ROBUST IMMUNE RESPONSE AGAINST THE INVADING PATHOGEN, GIVING RISE TO HOST IMMUNITY. OVER TIME, HOWEVER, THE PATHOGEN CAN EVOLVE TO OVERCOME THIS RESISTANCE. MANIPULATING SIGNAL TRANSDUCTION DOWNSTREAM OF THE RPS PROTEINS PROVIDES AN ALTERNATIVE STRATEGY TO INCREASE THE DURABILITY OF THE HOST RESISTANCE. WE HYPOTHESIZE THAT EPIGENETIC CHANGES, INCLUDING DNA METHYLATION, ARE CRUCIAL IN THIS SIGNALING PROCESS. THEREFORE, THIS PROJECT WILL INVESTIGATE HOW DNA METHYLATION REGULATES THE SIGNALING COMPONENTS IN RPS-MEDIATED IMMUNE RESPONSE. SECONDLY, TO ACHIEVE THE EDUCATIONAL GOAL, THE PROJECT WILL TRAIN STUDENTS FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS IN STEM AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS ENTERING THE STEM FIELD. THE COALITION BUILT WITH IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY AND THE ARKANSASSAS STATE UNIVERSITY GENERATES A CRITICAL MASS OF EXPERTISE AND ACTIVITY. IT STRENGTHENS THE SCOPE AND QUALITY OF THE PROJECT'S IMPACT, WHICH WILL BUILD ARKANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY'S CAPACITY TO COMPETE FOR FEDERAL GRANTS.
ENHANCING THE CAPACITY OF FOOD AND NUTRITION EDUCATION THROUGH INTEGRATED RESEARCH BASED PEDAGOGICAL PRACTICES

CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT HYDROPONIC PRODUCTION SYSTEMS ARE INCREASINGLY GAINING TRACTION FOR EFFICIENT AND SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION OF HIGH-VALUES VEGETABLE CROPS IN URBAN AND PERI-URBAN COMMUNITIES, GENERATING AN ARRAY OF RESEARCH AND TRAINING NEEDS TO SUPPORT THIS EMERGING INDUSTRY. TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY COMMERCE IS EXPANDING WITH THE CREATION OF A NEW PROGRAM OF BACHELOR OF SCIENCE IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE TRAINING OF PROFESSIONALS WITH EXCEPTIONAL SKILLS IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. THIS INTEGRATED-JOINT PROJECT BETWEEN A&M-COMMERCE AND TEXAS A&M AGRILIFE RESEARCH WILL STRENGTHEN THE UNIVERSITY CAPACITY IN DELIVERING INNOVATIVE EDUCATIONAL TRAINING BASED ON EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING RELATED TO CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT HYDROPONIC PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL ALLOW THE TWO INSTITUTIONS TO COLLABORATIVELY ADDRESS CRITICAL NEED IN APPLIED RESEARCH TO GENERATE SCIENCE-BASED BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR ENHANCING PRODUCTIVITY WITH THESE SYSTEMS AND ADVANCE SUSTAINABLE URBAN AGRICULTURE IN TEXAS AND BEYOND. SPECIFIC RESEARCH ACTIVITIES INCLUDE 1) DEVELOPING OPTIMUM PRACTICES FOR AN EFFICIENT AND YEAR-ROUND PRODUCTION OF LETTUCE IN CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT HYDROPONIC SYSTEMS, AND 2) EVALUATING THE EFFECTIVENESSOFVEGETABLE GRAFTING TECHNIQUE FOR EFFICIENT HYDROPONIC TOMATO PRODUCTION IN PROTECTED STRUCTURES. EDUCATION NEED AREAS WILL BE ADDRESSED BY ENHANCING THE SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE CURRICULUM WITH HANDS-ON BASIC RESEARCH PROJECTS AND STUDENT-CENTERED EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING COURSES TO CULTIVATE PROFESSIONALS WITH COMPETENCIES IN CONTROLLED ENVIRONMENT HYDROPONIC PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. BY ADVANCING SUSTAINABLE URBAN VEGETABLE PRODUCTION AND PREPARING NEW GENERATION OF SKILLFUL AND CAREER-READY AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS WITH HANDS-ON RESEARCH EXPERIENCE, THE GOAL AND ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT WILL CLEARLY ADVANCE THE OVERALL GOALS OF NLGCA PROGRAM.

THIS INTEGRATED PROPOSAL GROWS THE CAPACITY OF THE OHIO UNIVERSITY STUDENT FARM AND ALIGNS WITH NLGCA NEED AREAS IN OUTREACH AND EDUCATION AND ACADEMIC DISCIPLINE CODES G & S. WE WILL ENGAGE A TEAM OF LOCAL AGRICULTURAL EXPERTS, AND PARTNER WITH RURAL ACTION (RA) AND COMMUNITY FOOD INITIATIVES (CFI), TWO LOCAL NON-PROFITS THAT HAVE SIGNIFICANT COMMITMENT AND EXPERIENCE EDUCATING FARMERS AND INCREASING ACRES OF FARMED LAND AND FOOD SECURITY IN SOUTHEASTERN OHIO. OHIO WILL DEVELOP AN INNOVATIVE, SUSTAINABLE, FARM MANAGEMENT PLAN AND HIRE A FARM MANAGER TO IMPLEMENT IT. WE WILL BRING ELECTRICITY TO THE FARM THAT HAS NONE BY ENGAGING OHIO ENGINEERING STUDENTS TO DESIGN AND BUILD A SOLAR ARRAY, MAKING THE FARM A SUSTAINABLE ENTERPRISE. THE SOLAR ARRAY WILL POWER A COOLER TO KEEP PRODUCE FRESH WHILE AWAITING TRANSPORT FOR SALE OR DONATION. WE WILL ADD A HIGH TUNNEL EXTENDING OUR GROWING SEASON AND PRODUCTIVITY. WE WILL TRANSITION PARTS OF THE FARM TO ORGANIC PRODUCTION EXPANDING OUR EDUCATIONAL, RESEARCH AND MARKETING OPPORTUNITIES. OHIO WILL LEVERAGE THE FARM'S NEW RESOURCES & RA'S EXPERTISE TO DELIVER WORKSHOPS AND PEER TO PEER LEARNING TO TRAIN STUDENTS, FACULTY AND NEW FARMERS AND PROVIDE ESTABLISHED FARMERS WITH NEW WAYS TO PRODUCE INCOME. OHIO AND RA WILL RECRUIT, ENGAGE AND OHIO WILL TRAIN HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS AND UNDERGRADUATES IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND FOOD PRODUCTION. OHIO WILL GROW AND CFI WILL MAKE AVAILABLE HEALTHY PRODUCE FOR FOOD INSECURE POPULATIONS IN SOUTH EAST OHIO. THROUGH THIS INTEGRATED PROPOSAL, WE COMBINE RA'S EXTENSIVE OUTREACH AND PEER TO PEER LEARNING PORTFOLIO WITH THE FARM'S UNIQUE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES AND OHIO'S ENVIRONMENTAL AND ECOLOGICAL SCIENCES CURRICULA TO EDUCATE AND INSPIRE STUDENTS AND FARMERS ALIKE.

THE DWINDLING NUMBER OF EXPERIENCED PLANT BREEDERS IN THE US AND THE LACK OF QUALIFIED INDIVIDUALS TO REPLACE THEM PUTS THE NATIONAL FOOD SYSTEM AT CRITICAL RISK AND SERIOUSLY COMPROMISES THE CAPACITY OF LEARNING INSTITUTIONS TO EDUCATE FUTURE PLANT BREEDERS. INCREASING THE QUANTITY AND QUALITY OF NEXT-GENERATION PLANT BREEDERS WILL REQUIRE RE-INVENTING EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMS TO RECRUIT, TRAIN AND PREPARE A DIVERSE GROUP OF STUDENTS FOR A COMPETITIVE CAREER PATH IN PLANT BREEDING. THE OVERALL GOALS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT ARE TO (1) RAISE INTEREST IN PLANT BREEDING AMONG UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND ENCOURAGE THEM TO PURSUE GRADUATE DEGREES AND PROFESSIONAL CAREERS IN THE FIELD, AND (2) ENSURE THAT GRADUATE STUDENT EDUCATION IN PLANT BREEDING APPROPRIATELY PREPARES STUDENTS FOR FUTURE JOBS IN EITHER THE PUBLIC OR PRIVATE SECTOR. THESE GOALS WILL BE ACHIEVED BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR PLANT BREEDING-RELATED INTERNSHIPS TO TWELVE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND A GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIP TO ONE PHD STUDENT FROM UNDERREPRESENTED AND/OR ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED SECTORS IN THE US. OPPORTUNITIES THAT CAN FURTHER ENHANCE THE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE AND PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF THE STUDENTS THROUGH MENTORING, NETWORKING, AND PARTICIPATION IN SCIENTIFIC MEETINGS AND FARMER FIELD DAYS WILL ALSO BE PROVIDED. TO ENSURE WORKFORCE PREPAREDNESS, TRAINING OF THE PHD STUDENT WILL BE BASED ON A CAREFULLY DESIGNED STUDY PLAN THAT INTEGRATES FUNDAMENTAL KNOWLEDGE IN PLANT BREEDING WITH PRACTICAL SKILLS THROUGH APPLIED RESEARCH AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING. THE INTERNSHIP AND RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES THAT WILL BE PROVIDED TO THE STUDENTS WILL CENTER ON OPERATIONS RELATED TO CONTEMPORARY RICE BREEDING.PROVIDING FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING THROUGH INTERNSHIP EXPERIENCES AND GRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCH, AS WELL AS FOR PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WILL ENCOURAGE INTEREST IN THE DISCIPLINE AND INCREASE THE REPRESENTATION OF MINORITY AND ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED GROUPS IN PLANT BREEDING-RELATED WORKFORCE. THESE WILL BE CRITICAL IN STEMMING THE CONTINUOUS DECLINE IN THE NUMBER OF QUALIFIED PLANT BREEDERS IN THE US TOWARDS SUSTAINING THE PLANT BREEDING CAPACITY IN THE COUNTRY.

THE CAL POLY BULL TEST HAS SERVED AS AN INVALUABLE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITY FOR UNDERGRADUATES FOR 65 YEARS. ADDITIONALLY, THE PROGRAM PROVIDES A VALUABLE SERVICE TO BULL BREEDERS AND BUYERS IN CALIFORNIA AS THE ONLY BULL TEST REMAINING IN THE STATE. HOWEVER, THE CURRENT PROGRAM LACKS THE INFRASTRUCTURE TO PROVIDE CUTTING EDGE RESEARCH, SERVICE, AND OUTREACH TO BEEF PRODUCERS. OUR OBJECTIVE IS TO SUCCESSFULLY INTEGRATE TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH EFFORTS TO THE PROGRAM TO IMPROVE THE SERVICE WE CURRENTLY PROVIDE; THUS, THE PROPOSED INTEGRATED PROJECT IS A MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, SAN LUIS OBISPO (CAL POLY), CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, CHICO, AND UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF ALL INSTITUTIONS TO ASSESS BULL MANAGEMENT PRACTICESWE PLAN TO ASSESS THE GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT OF YEARLING BULLS WITH THE FOLLOWING METRICS: BULL BEHAVIORAL TRAITS ASSOCIATED WITH PHYSICAL FITNESS/ACTIVITY ANDLIBIDO, METABOLOMIC MARKERS IN SEMINAL FLUID AND SERUM ASSOCIATED WITH FERTILITY, AND PENILE AND SEMINAL FLUID MICROBIOME EFFECTS ON FERTILITY. WE ALSO STRIVE TO BUILD A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, CHICO (ANOTHER NON-LAND GRANT UNIVERSITY) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF WYOMING WHEREIN A STUDENT EXCHANGE AND INTERNSHIP PROGRAM WILL BE DEVELOPED. FURTHERMORE, OUTREACH EFFORTS TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES OF BULL MANAGEMENT WILL BE REPLICATED AT THE PARTNER INSTITUTIONS. THIS PROJECT FULFILLS THE INTEGRATED, LARGE-SCALE COMPREHENSIVE INITIATIVES BY COMBINING AND IMPROVING THE TEACHING, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH MISSION OF THE CAL POLY BULL TEST. THESE INSTITUTIONS COMPLEMENT RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND OUTREACH EFFORTS BECAUSE OF DIFFERENCES IN BREEDING/CALVING SEASON AND BULL DEVELOPMENT PRACTICES. THE NATURE OF RESEARCH OF BEEF BULLS TYPICALLY RESULTS IN LOW ANIMAL NUMBERS. HOWEVER, THIS COLLABORATIVE EFFORT WILL STRENGTHEN THE PROJECT AND DATA INTEGRITY.

METHANE HAS NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON THE CLIMATE DUE TO ITS HIGH GLOBAL WARMING POTENTIAL. HUMAN ACTIVITIES SUCH AS AGRICULTURE, WASTE DISPOSAL AND FOSSIL FUEL PRODUCTION PRODUCE ABOUT 60% OF THE WORLD'S METHANE EMISSIONS THAT IS RESPONSIBLE FOR AT LEAST 25% OF TODAY'S GLOBAL WARMING. ENTERIC FERMENTATION AND MANURE MANAGEMENT ARE THE TWO PROCESSES PRODUCING METHANE IN LIVESTOCK. WASTING PART OF THE FEED ENERGY IN THE FORM OF METHANE IS NOT ONLY A CLIMATE ISSUE BUT ALSO A PRODUCTION PROBLEM. ACCORDING TO THE UNITED NATIONS, THE WORLD POPULATION IS ABOUT 7.7 BILLION IN 2019 AND EXPECTED TO GROW TO AROUND 8.5, 9.7 AND 10.9 BILLION IN 2030, 2050 AND 2100, RESPECTIVELY. THIS POPULATION GROWTH IS THE MAIN MOTIVATION OF THE INCREASED DEMAND FOR LIVESTOCK PRODUCTS. TO MEET THE GROWING GLOBAL DEMANDS OVER THE NEXT 50 YEARS, IT IS ESTIMATED THAT LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION SHOULD INCREASE BY 70%. THEREFORE, METHANE EMISSIONS ARE EXPECTED TO CONTINUE TO INCREASE AS THE DEMAND FOR ANIMAL PRODUCTS INCREASES. THEREFORE, SCIENTISTS HAVE BEEN INVESTIGATING DIFFERENT STRATEGIES TO REDUCE METHANE EMISSIONS AS COMMUNITIES BECAME MORE AWARE OF THE NEGATIVE IMPACT OF CLIMATE CHANGE ON THE ENVIRONMENT. MEASURING METHANE EMISSION ON A LARGE-SCALE LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION FARM IS CHALLENGING DUE TO THE HIGH COSTS AND THE LOW THROUGHPUT OF THE TRADITIONAL USED METHODS. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT A NUMBER OF EXPERIMENTS IN THE LAB AND FIELD TO DEVELOP A LOW COST AND A HIGHLY EFFICIENT SYSTEM THAT WILL BE ABLE TO MONITOR AND MEASURE METHANE EMISSION ON A LARGER SCALE USING COMPUTER VISION AND ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE TECHNIQUES. THE RESULTS OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED FOR PROMOTING GREENER LIVESTOCK AND DISSEMINATED IN A STRAIGHTFORWARD WAY TO LIVESTOCK PRODUCERSTHROUGH CONDUCTING WORKSHOPS AND ACCESSIBLE WEBSITE. THIS PROJECT WILL CONDUCT EDUCATION WORKSHOPS TO ANIMAL SCIENCE STUDENTS TO ENRICH THEIR SKILLS IN USING AI TECHNOLOGIES IN THE FIELD OF ANIMAL SCIENCE. IN CONCLUSION, THE EXPECTED OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT WILL BE USED BY LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS FOR BETTER MANAGEMENT PRACTICES SUCH AS CHOOSING THE OPTIMAL DIET FOR THEIR HERD AND MANURE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES THAT WILL HELP WITH REDUCING METHANE EMISSION.

DRY, LEGUMINOUS PLANT SEEDS CALLED PULSES INCLUDE A WIDE VARIETY OF BEANS, LENTILS, CHICKPEA, AND PEAS. OLIGOSACCHARIDES ARE MAJOR COMPONENTS IN PULSE, WHICH CONTAIN STACHYOSE, VERBASCOSE, AND HIGH AMOUNT OF RAFFINOSE. RECENT RESEARCHES SHOW THAT RAFFINOSE OLIGOSACCHARIDE (RFO) IS ASSOCIATED WITH A BENEFICIAL ROLE AS PREBIOTICS, WHICH SIGNIFICANTLY HELPS IN PROMOTING THE GUT-HEALTH AND GROWTH OF PROBIOTIC BACTERIA. IN THIS RESEARCH STUDY, WE WILL INVESTIGATE VARIETY OF PULSES, FOR THEIR RAFFINOSE OLIGOSACCHARIDE CONTENT. RFOS WILL BE EXTRACTED THROUGH SEVERAL PULSES AND METHOD OF EXTRACTION WILL BE OPTIMIZED. FURTHER, PREBIOTIC RFO POWDER WILL BE FORTIFIED IN FERMENTED PRODUCTS LIKE YOGURT FOR THEIR FOOD APPLICATIONS. FERMENTED MILK PRODUCTS SUCH AS YOGURT ARE ONE OF THE MOST POPULAR PROBIOTIC PRODUCTS. THEY OFFER HEALTH BENEFITS DUE TO FUNCTIONAL PROPERTIES OF ACTIVE PROBIOTIC BACTERIA. UNFORTUNATELY, IT IS DIFFICULT TO KEEP BACTERIA VIABLE DURING STORAGE OF FERMENTED PRODUCTS. THEREFORE, THE PROPOSED STUDY WILL FOCUS ON EXTRACTION, CHARACTERIZATION, AND EVALUATION OF PULSE PREBIOTICS ON PHYSIOCHEMICAL, TEXTURAL, SENSORY QUALITY AND SHELF LIFE OF YOGURT. THIS STUDY WILL PROVIDE DATA ON THE EFFECT OF PULSE PREBIOTICS AS A FOOD INGREDIENT IN FERMENTED FOODS, IN THIS CASE, YOGURT. THIS WILL ALSO HELP IN IMPROVING OUR KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE PHYSICAL, CHEMICAL, AND BIOLOGICAL PROPERTIES OF PULSE PREBIOTICS AS A FOOD INGREDIENT.

LICENSED CHILDCARE CENTERS, MORE THAN 125,000 IN NUMBER SERVING APPROXIMATELY 12M CHILDREN NATIONWIDE, ARE IMPORTANT FACILITIES WITH PROFOUND IMPACTS ON CHILDREN'S HEALTH AND WELLBEING. DESIGN-BASED INTERVENTIONS IN CHILDCARE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS WERE FOUND TO SUPPORT CHILDREN'S INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY (PA) AND HEALTHY DIET; THE TWO MOST IMPORTANT CRITERIA FOR PREVENTING EARLY CHILDHOOD OBESITY. HOWEVER, TRAINING CHILDCARE PROVIDERS AND STAKEHOLDERS ABOUT IMPLEMENTING HEALTHY OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS AND DISSEMINATING REQUIRED RESOURCES FOR A COST-EFFECTIVE IMPLEMENTATION ARE CHALLENGING. FIELD TRIPS TO DEMONSTRATION SITES OFFER AN OPPORTUNITY TO MOTIVATE AND CONNECT CHILDCARE PROVIDERS TO ENCOURAGE AND EDUCATE THEM ABOUT SUCH HEALTHY AND ACTIVE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS FOR CHILDREN. BUT EDUCATIONAL FIELD TRIPS ARE NOT ONLY EXPENSIVE BUT ARE ALSO TIME-CONSUMING FOR CARE PROVIDERS WHO ARE CONSTANTLY MANAGING A HEAVY WORKLOAD AND STRUGGLING TO STAFF THEIR CENTERS DUE TO A HIGH RATE OF TURNOVERS. INTERNET-BASED VIRTUAL FIELD TRIPS USING THE LATEST 3D CAMERA TECHNOLOGY MAY OVERCOME THESE CONSTRAINTS RELATED TO BUDGET AND TIME. ADDITIONALLY, INTERACTIVE VIRTUAL TOURS (IVTS) THAT EMBED EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES WITHIN THE VIRTUAL FIELD TRIP CAN PROVIDE AN INNOVATIVE, ENGAGING, AND COST-EFFECTIVE WAY OF DISSEMINATING TRAINING RESOURCES TO CHILDCARE PROVIDERS. TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY (TTU) PROPOSES THIS JOINT PROJECT IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NATIONAL WILDLIFE FEDERATION (NWF) TO CREATE AN ONLINE TRAINING MODULE USING INTERACTIVE VIRTUAL TOURS (IVTS) TO TRAIN CHILDCARE PROVIDERS AND CAREGIVERS AND DISSEMINATE RESOURCES TO CREATE HEALTHY AND ACTIVE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS FOR 0-5 YEARS OLD CHILDREN IN US LICENSED CHILDCARE CENTERS. PARALLEL TO TRAINING CHILDCARE PERSONNEL, THE PROJECT ALSO AIMS TO TRAIN AND EDUCATE FUTURE LEADERS ABOUT THE CRITICAL NEEDS OF HEALTHY AND ACTIVE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS IN EARLY CHILDHOOD INSTITUTES. THIS IS WHY THE NEWLY CREATED IVTS WILL BE REUSED ASINSTRUCTIONAL MODULES IN FOR-CREDIT COURSES FOR TEXAS TECH STUDENTS IN FAMILY STUDIES AND DESIGN AND TWO ONLINE CERTIFICATE COURSES FOR DESIGN PROFESSIONALS. FINALLY, A SIGNIFICANT PART OF THE PROJECT WILL BE DEDICATED TO EVALUATING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF IVT-BASED INSTRUCTIONAL MODULES FOR TRAINING TARGETED AUDIENCES ABOUT DESIGN INTERVENTIONS IN CHILDCARE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS TO PROMOTE CHILDREN'S HEALTH AND WELLBEING.THE PROJECT WILL LEVERAGE ALREADY CREATED DEMONSTRATION SITES IN TEXAS (1 SITE) AND COLORADO (2 SITES) WHICH WERE DEVELOPED BY TTU (IN TEXAS) AND NWF (IN COLORADO) AND CONTAIN THE BEST PRACTICES OF OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENT DESIGN FOR PROMOTING PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND HEALTHY DIETS AMONG CHILDREN. SUCH INTERVENTIONS INCLUDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CHILDREN TO BE INVOLVED IN HANDS-ON FRUIT AND VEGETABLE GARDENING, CONCRETE PATHWAYS TO INCREASE CHILDREN'S MOVEMENT BEHAVIORS, AMPLE SHADE PROTECTIONS TO PROVIDE SAFE AND COMFORTABLE CONDITIONS YEAR-ROUND FOR CHILDREN'S PHYSICALACTIVITIES, ETC. IVTS WILL BE CREATED BY EMBEDDING NEW AND EXISTING MULTIMEDIA RESOURCES IN THE VIRTUAL TOURS. THESE IVTS WILL BE USED TO DESIGN A SYNCHRONOUS WORKSHOP MODULE FOR CHILDCARE PROVIDERS WHO ARE INTERESTED TO TRANSFORM THEIR OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS INTO HEALTHY AND ACTIVE ONES. USING THE IVT-BASED MODULE, TTU AND NWF WILL ORGANIZE TWO INTERACTIVE ONLINE WORKSHOPS - ONE IN TEXAS AND ONE IN COLORADO. FROM WORKSHOP PARTICIPANTS, 4 CENTERS WILL BE SELECTED (2 IN TEXAS AND 2 IN COLORADO) FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF HEALTHY OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS. THESE 4 CENTERS WILL RECEIVE SEED GRANTS FROM THE PROJECT AND IVT-BASED TRAINING RESOURCES TO GUIDE THE IMPLEMENTATIONS. AFTER COMPLETING THE INTERVENTIONS, NEW IVT RESOURCES WILL BE CREATED FROM 3D IMAGERY OF THESE FOUR SITES. IVT RESOURCES CREATED IN THE PROJECT WILL BE MODIFIED/EDITED TO CREATE INSTRUCTIONAL MATERIALS FOR FOUR FOR-CREDIT UNDERGRADUATE- AND GRADUATE-LEVEL TTU COURSES AND TWO CERTIFICATE COURSES (BY TTU AND NWF) TO TRAIN FUTURE LEADERS AND DESIGN PROFESSIONALS ABOUT HEALTHY OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENT INTERVENTIONS. ONLINE SURVEYS FOR STUDENTS AND INSTRUCTORS WILL BE USED TO COLLECT LEARNER AND EDUCATOR FEEDBACK. TWO FOCUS GROUPS WILL BE ORGANIZED TO COLLECT IN-DEPTH DATA REGARDING THE EFFECTIVENESS OF IVT RESOURCES. ANALYTICS DATA FROM WEBSITES, ONLINE COURSE PORTALS (BLACKBOARD AND MS TEAMS), AND IVTS WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED TO MEASURE THE ENGAGEMENT AND INTERACTIVITY OF USERS.TRAINING CHILDCARE PROVIDERS AND EDUCATING FUTURE LEADERS USING ENGAGING AND INTERACTIVE IVT RESOURCES WILL POTENTIALLY SPREAD A CULTURE OF HEALTH INITIALLY AMONG THE TARGETED TEXAS AND COLORADO CHILDCARE COMMUNITIES. BUT CONSIDERING THE NATIONAL REACH OF THE PARTNERING ORGANIZATION NWF, THE IVTS AND IVT-BASED TRAINING RESOURCES CAN BE DISSEMINATED TO A NATIONAL AUDIENCE BEYOND TEXAS AND COLORADO. A WEB LIBRARY OF IVTS DEMONSTRATING HIGH-QUALITY HEALTHY AND ACTIVE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS IN CHILDCARE CENTERS WILL BE HOSTED ON THE NWF WEBSITE WHICH WILL BE OPEN AND ACCESSIBLE TO ALL INTERESTED AUDIENCES. REMOVING THE BARRIERS OF FIELD TRIPS TO CHILDCARE DEMONSTRATION SITES BY PROVIDING AN ALTERNATIVE SOLUTION, THE PROJECT WOULD CREATE POSSIBILITIES FOR MORE DIALOGUE, LATERAL LEARNING, AND PEER INTERACTIONS AMONG CHILDCARE PROVIDERS INTERESTED IN TRANSFORMING THEIR OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS TO GENERATE INCREASED PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND HEALTHY EATING BEHAVIORS AMONG CHILDREN. THE PROJECT ALSO REIMAGINES THE ONLINE EDUCATION SYSTEM BY PROVIDING A NEW AND ENGAGING WAY FOR INSTRUCTORS FOR DELIVERING EDUCATIONAL CONTENT TO THEIR STUDENTS OUTSIDE THE RIGID FRAMEWORK OF ONLINE COURSE PLATFORMS.THE ASSOCIATION BETWEEN CHILDCARE ATTENDANCE AND THE RISK OF OBESITY IN CHILDREN IS OF CRITICAL IMPORTANCE AND DEMANDS SPECIAL ATTENTION, ESPECIALLY BECAUSE A LARGE NUMBER OF INFANTS AND YOUNG CHILDREN (0-5 YEARS) IN THE UNITED STATES SPEND A MAJORITY OF THEIR WAKING HOURS IN SOME TYPE OF EARLY CARE SETTINGS EACH DAY. LICENSED CHILDCARE CENTERS, THEREFORE, CAN PLAY A SIGNIFICANT ROLE IN CHILDREN'S HEALTH AND WELLBEING BY IMPROVING THEIR OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS. INNOVATION IS NEEDED TO PROMOTE A CULTURE OF HEALTH BY TRANSFORMING CHILDCARE OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS AND INCORPORATING DESIGN BEST PRACTICES TO ENCOURAGE CHILDREN'S NATURE INTERACTIONS, PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, AND HEALTHY EATING. THE PROPOSED PROJECT CAN POTENTIALLY PLAY A CRITICAL ROLE IN THE LICENSED CHILDCARE ENTERPRISE BY INCREASING THE PRACTICE AND VISIBILITY OF USING HEALTHY AND ACTIVE OUTDOORS FOR IMPROVING DIET AND PHYSICAL ACTIVITIES. WITH GROWING INTEREST FROM EARLY CHILDHOOD PROGRAMS TO RE-IMAGINE OUTDOOR PLAY AND LEARNING SPACES, GUIDANCE FROM THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) TO SPEND MORE TIME OUTDOORS TO REDUCE COVID VIRUS TRANSMISSION, AND NEW HEAD START GUIDANCE ENCOURAGING PROGRAMS TO SPEND AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN RELIEF FUNDS ON OUTDOOR CLASSROOMS AND GARDENS IN LIEU OF TRADITIONAL PLAY EQUIPMENT, CREATING ACCESSIBLE TOOLS FOR SUPPORTING PROVIDERS IN THIS WORK IS CRITICAL. THE PROJECT IS A STRONG CANDIDATE FOR HIGHER LEVELS OF FUNDING. THE PROJECT AIMS TO EXPAND BEYOND THE PROPOSED GRANT PERIOD BY GRADUALLY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF VIRTUAL TOURS PROMOTING CHILDCARE HEALTHY OUTDOOR ENVIRONMENTS WHICH MAY LEAD TO ADOPTING VIRTUAL TOUR BASED CHILDCARE HEALTH PROMOTION AS A NATION-WIDE STRATEGY. TO ACHIEVE THE GOAL, THE PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE VIRTUAL TOURS WITH RECOGNIZED MAPPING AND CENSUS PLATFORMS AND COLLABORATE WITH EARLY CHILDHOOD ORGANIZATIONS - HEAD START, SMART START, NAAEE, NAEYC, ETC. THE PROJECT WILL BE PIONEERING IN ITS FIELD AS IT OFFERS A NEW TAKE ON EVIDENCE-SHARING AND INTEGRATES A SUCCESSFUL INTERNET-BASED MARKETING STRATEGY TO PROMOTE A CULTURE OF OUTDOOR HEALTH.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE A COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH INITIATIVE BETWEEN THREE INSTITUTIONS--TARLETON STATE UNIVERSITY, TEXAS A&M AGRILIFE RESEARCH-STEPHENVILLE, AND TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY-KINGSVILLE--WITH THE FOCUS OF CONSERVING POLLINATORS IN GRASSLANDS IN THE SOUTHERN GREAT PLAINS.POLLINATOR INSECTS ARE IN DECLINE IN MUCH OF THE UNITED STATES, WHICH PROVIDES OVER $39 BILLION PER YEAR IN POLLINATION SERVICES FOR AGRICULTURAL CROPS. THERE IS NO SINGLE LEADING CAUSE OF THIS DECLINE, BUT THE LOSS OF NATIVE FLOWERING PLANTS THAT POLLINATORS RECOGNIZE AS A FOOD SOURCE IS A CONTRIBUTING FACTOR. AT THE SAME TIME, OVER 40% OF THE UNITED STATES IS COMPOSED OF WORKING LANDS, WHICH INCLUDES FARMS, RANGELANDS, AND OTHER LANDSCAPES FORMERLY DOMINATED BY NATIVE GRASS BUT HAVE BEEN REPLACED BY NON-NATIVE VEGETATION. REPLACING NON-NATIVE VEGETATION WITH NATIVE VEGETATION CAN IMPROVE FORAGE FOR BIRDS AND POLLINATORS BUT ALSO PROVIDE IMPORTANT ECOSYSTEM SERVICES, SUCH AS TOLERATINGDROUGHT. GRASSES, WHICH NORMALLY ARE NOT CONSIDERED A SOURCE OF FOOD FOR POLLINATORS, MAY PRODUCE POLLEN THAT IS READILY ACCEPTED BY BEES, FLIES, AND OTHER POLLINATING INSECTS, AND GIVEN THAT GRASS POLLEN MAY HAVE HIGHER STARCH AND WATER CONTENT THAN OTHER FLOWERING PLANTS, GRASS POLLEN MAY BE AN IMPORTANT RESOURCE FOR POLLINATORS DURING TIMES OF DROUGHT.IN SUMMATION, WE SIMPLY DO NOT KNOW HOW CRITICAL GRASS POLLEN IS FOR SUSTAINING INSECT POLLINATOR POPULATIONS IN WORKING LANDS IN THE US, AND SEEK TO IDENTIFY A SUPPLEMENTAL RESOURCE THAT CAN PROVIDE BENEFITS TO POLLINATORS DURING PERIODS WHERE OTHER RESOURCES ARE LIMITED. OUR COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH WILL HELP IDENTIFY A SUITE OF GRASS SPECIES THAT COULD BE INCLUDED INTO "POLLINATOR-FRIENDLY" PLANTINGS OR LEAD TO PLANT TRIALS FOR COMMERCIAL USE IN LANDSCAPES, RANGELANDS, AND RESTORATION ACROSS NORTH-CENTRAL TEXAS, WITH EXPECTATIONS TO EXPAND OUR FINDINGS TO HELP IMPROVE RESTORATION EFFORTS THROUGH THE SOUTHERN GREAT PLAINS.

WITH THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR "LOCAL" FOODS, FARMERS MARKETS ARE BECOMING A SIGNIFICANT AND INTEGRATED PART OF THE LOCAL FOOD SYSTEM. WITH MANY FARMERS MOVING INTO THE BUSINESS OF PROCESSING AND SELLING THEIR OWN MEAT AND POULTRY, IT IS BECOMING MORE EVIDENT THAT THESE PRODUCTS ARE GENERALLY LESS REGULATED AND MAY COME WITH THEIR OWN FOOD SAFETY RISKS. THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL, INTERDISCIPLINARY, INTEGRATED PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE THE SAFETY OF MEAT AND POULTRY AT FARMERS MARKETS AND OTHER SOURCES OF DIRECT FARMER-TO-CONSUMER SALES THROUGH INTEGRATING EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. THIS GOAL WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED BY 1) ENHANCING THE FOOD SCIENCE CURRICULUM AND RESEARCH CAPACITY AT WESTERN KENTUCKY UNIVERSITY, 2) TRAINING THE NEXT GENERATION OF AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SCIENCE STUDENTS WITH EXPERIENTIAL SKILLS, 3) COLLECTING MUCH-NEEDED DATA ON MICROBIAL SAFETY OF PROCESSED MEAT AND POULTRY, 4) ASSESSING KNOWLEDGE AND PRACTICES OF FARMERS MARKET VENDORS, 5)EVALUATING CONSUMERS' PERCEPTIONS OF MEAT AND POULTRY SAFETY RISKS, AND 6) ESTABLISHING AN INFRASTRUCTURE FOR SMALL MEAT AND POULTRY PROCESSORS AND VENDORS TO DEVELOP INNOVATIVE STRATEGIES TO CONTROL PATHOGENIC MICROORGANISMS ON MEAT AND POULTRY PRODUCTS AND TO GAIN THE KNOWLEDGE TO ENSURE BOTH FOOD SAFETY AND THE PROFITABILITY. THIS PROJECT IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN WESTERN KENTUCKY UNIVERSITY, WEST VIRGINIA UNIVERSITY, AND WAYNE STATE UNIVERSITY TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS ENTERING FOOD AND AGRICULTURE-RELATED SCIENCE AND ENHANCE FOOD SAFETY THAT WILL LEAD TO PROMOTING RURAL PROSPERITY AND ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT TO MEAT AND POULTRY FARMERS.

THE DAIRY INDUSTRY IS UNDERGOING MANY STRUCTURAL CHANGES WHICH HAS SIGNIFICANT IMPLICATIONS FOR ITS LONG-TERM PROFITABILITY. THE COMBINATION OF THE SHIFT AWAY FROM FLUID MILK AND INCREASED DOMESTIC PRODUCTION HAVE LED TO OVERSUPPLY, LOW MILK PRICES, AND A SIGNIFICANT LOSS OF FARM INCOME. AT THE SAME TIME, THE MARKET FOR NON-DAIRY MILK IS RAPIDLY INCREASING. PART OF THESE CHANGES IN CONSUMPTION ARE DRIVEN BY CONCERNS ABOUT THE TREATMENT OF FARM ANIMALS. USING A MULTI-STAKEHOLDER APPROACH THIS STUDY EXAMINES FARMER AND CONSUMER DECISION-MAKING PERTAINING TO THE PRACTICE OF EARLY CALF DAM SEPARATION, A MAJOR PUBLIC CONCERN, AND ITS IMPLICATIONS FOR THE SOCIAL SUSTAINABILITY OF THE DAIRY INDUSTRY. WE ALSO EXAMINE THE ROLE OF MILK PROCESSORS IN THE CREATION OF VALUE ADDED SUPPLY CHAINS FOR THESE ATTRIBUTES. DATA ARE FROM A SAMPLE OF DAIRY FARMERS AND PROCESSORS IN MAJOR DAIRY PRODUCING STATES IN THE US. DATA FROM A NATIONAL REPRESENTATIVE SAMPLE OF US DAIRY CONSUMERS WILL ALSO BE COLLECTED.THIS IS A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PROJECT THAT BRINGS TOGETHER FACULTY AND STUDENT RESEARCHERS FROM DAIRY SCIENCE AND AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS. THE STUDY INTEGRATES INSIGHTS FROM SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH ON ALTERNATIVE CALF-DAM MANAGEMENT METHODS INTO FARMER,PROCESSOR AND CONSUMER/PUBLIC STATED PREFERENCE ANALYSIS TO IDENTIFY POTENTIAL POINTS OF CONVERGENCE. WE PROVIDE UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS AND GENERATE EVIDENCE-BASED INSIGHTS FOR TRAINING STUDENTS IN THE DAIRY SCIENCE AND AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS PROGRAMS. INSIGHTS FROM THIS STUDY CAN INFORM INDUSTRY STRATEGIES AND HELP THE DAIRY INDUSTRY TO ACHIEVE THE TRIPLE GOALS OF HIGHER SOCIAL SUSTAINABILITY, IMPROVED LONG-TERM PROFITABILITY AND ENHANCED FARM ANIMAL WELFARE.

THOUGH CALIFORNIA PRODUCES MORE MILK THAN ANY OTHER STATE, ITS DAIRY BUSINESSES FACE SIGNIFICANTCHALLENGES: VOLATILE FLUID MILK PRICES, DECLINING DEMAND, AN ACUTE LABOR SHORTAGE, AND INCREASEDCOSTS. THESE IMPACTS RIPPLE THROUGHOUT CALIFORNIA'S DAIRY INDUSTRY, RESPONSIBLE FOR 55,000 MILKPRODUCTION AND PROCESSING JOBS AT 150 DAIRY-RELATED PROCESSING FACILITIES. AT THE SAME TIME, THENUMBER OF POSTSECONDARY STUDENTS ENTERING FOOD AND AGRICULTURE-RELATED STEM DISCIPLINES ISDECLINING. GIVEN THE TREMENDOUS NEED TO RESTORE PROFITABILITY TO CALIFORNIA DAIRY BUSINESSES, ADDRESSTHE WORKFORCE SHORTAGE, AND INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS ENTERING STEMPROGRAMS, CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, FRESNO (FRESNO STATE), A NON-LAND GRANT COLLEGE OFAGRICULTURE (NLGCA) IS PROPOSING A COLLABORATIVE LARGE-SCALE COMPREHENSIVE INITIATIVE (LCI). THEPROJECT GOAL IS TO GENERATE A CRITICAL MASS OF EXPERTISE, SKILL, AND TECHNOLOGY TO BUILD FRESNO STATE'SCAPACITY, PRIMARILY IN THE FOOD SCIENCE/TECHNOLOGY AND MANUFACTURING DISCIPLINE (CODE F). THECALIFORNIA DAIRY INNOVATION CENTER AND LEPRINO FOODS WILL PARTNER IN THIS EFFORT TO ACCOMPLISHPROJECT OBJECTIVES, INCLUDING: 1) EXPANDING FRESNO STATE'S DAIRY PILOT-PLANT CAPACITY BY ACQUIRINGSTATE-OF-THE-ART EQUIPMENT; 2) ESTABLISHING AN INSTITUTE FOR ETHNIC AND SPECIALTY DAIRY PRODUCTDEVELOPMENT 3) INCREASING THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS ENTERING THE DAIRY INDUSTRY THROUGHA PRIVATE SECTOR COLLABORATION TO FORMALIZE STUDENT INTERNSHIPS; AND 4) PROVIDING OUTREACH ANDTECHNICAL ASSISTANCE TO DAIRY BUSINESSES AND THEIR WORKFORCE. THIS IS HIGHLY RELEVANT AND DIRECTLYALIGNS WITH THE NLGCA'S PRIORITIES TO INCREASE THE NUMBER AND DIVERSITY OF STUDENTS ENTERING STEMFIELDS; TO BUILD LINKAGES WITH OTHER INSTITUTIONS; AND TO ADDRESS A SPECIFIC NEED AREA.

SUSTAINABLE INTENSIFICATION OF AGRICULTURE REQUIRES SOLUTIONS TO INCREASE FOOD PRODUCTION CAPACITY WHILE MINIMIZING ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACTS. CURRENTLY, THE INEFFICIENT CYCLING OF NUTRIENTS ON FARMS RESULT IN THE DETERIORATION OF AIR AND WATER QUALITY. PYROLYSIS HAS THE POTENTIAL TO IMPROVE AGRICULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY. HOWEVER, BIOCHAR HAS PRIMARILY BEEN STUDIED IN AGRICULTURE AS AN AMENDMENT TO AGRONOMIC SOILS TO FOSTER SOIL HEALTH, REDUCE NUTRIENT LEACHING AND SEQUESTER CARBON. WE PURPOSE TO CONDUCT A VARIETY OF STUDIES LOOKING AT DIFFERENT USES OF BIOCHAR AT LIVESTOCK FACILITIES FOR IMPROVING WATER AND AIR QUALITY OUTCOMES, WHILE ALSO BUILDING CAPACITY AT UW-PLATTEVILLE FOR FUTURE ON-FARM BIOCHAR RESEARCH STUDIES. AT UW-PLATTEVILLE A PILOT SCALE PYROLYSIS REACTOR WILL BE INSTALLED TO PRODUCE BIOCHAR FOR PILOT/PLOT SCALE RESEARCH PROJECTS. WHILE THE SYSTEM WILL BE INSTALLED AT UW-PLATTEVILLE, A WISCONSIN BIOCHAR RESEARCH HUB WILL BE ESTABLISHED BETWEEN UW-PLATTEVILLE, UW-GREEN BAY AND UW-MADISON PROVIDING ACCESS TO EQUIPMENT, BENEFITING BIOCHAR RESEARCH AT ALL INSTITUTIONS INTO THE FUTURE. EACH CAMPUS WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR CONDUCTING SPECIFIC RESEARCH OBJECTIVES. GRADUATE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WILL BE INTEGRATED INTO ALL ASPECTS OF THE PROJECT AT ALL UNIVERSITIES PROVIDING THEM WITH HANDS-ON AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES. RESEARCH STUDIES CONDUCTED ON BIOCHARS USES IN AGRICULTURE WILL TARGET ON-FARM AND EDGE OF FIELD NUTRIENT RECOVERY SYSTEMS, PHOSPHORUS DENSIFICATION OF MANURE THROUGH PYROLYSIS, AND REDUCING GREENHOUSE GAS EMISSIONS.

THE INTEGRATION OF NEW SENSORS AND DIGITAL TECHNOLOGIES IS MOVING AGRICULTURE TOWARD A NEW REVOLUTION THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE EXPONENTIAL GAIN IN PRODUCTIVITY NEEDED TO FEED A GROWING POPULATION WHILE BEING RESPECTFUL OF THE ENVIRONMENT. CSU FRESNO IS IN THE CENTER OF THE MOST PRODUCTIVE AGRICULTURAL AREA IN THE UNITED STATES: THE SAN JOAQUIN VALLEY, GLOBALLY RECOGNIZED FOR SPECIALTY CROP PRODUCTION. CURRENT REMOTE SENSING TECHNOLOGIES WERE DESIGNED TO FULFILL THE NEEDS OF FIELD CROP PRODUCTION, BUT AN INCREASE IN RESOLUTION IS NEEDED TO SUCCESSFULLY DEPLOY THESE TOOLS IN A CONTEXT WHERE EACH PLANT HAS A HIGH VALUE AND COULD BE MANAGED INDIVIDUALLY. THE RAPID DEVELOPMENT OF REMOTE SENSING SERVICES DEMONSTRATES THE CRITICAL NEED OF THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY FOR THESE TECHNOLOGIES; HOWEVER, BOTH FUNDAMENTAL AND APPLIED SCIENCE ARE NEEDED TO DEVELOP APPLICATIONS THAT CAN ADDRESS REAL-WORLD PROBLEMS AT SCALE. AT THE FOREFRONT OF THIS RESEARCH FIELD, WE REQUEST FUNDS TO PURCHASE EQUIPMENT THAT WILL COMPLEMENT OUR CURRENT HYPERSPECTRAL IMAGERY CAPABILITY TO PROVIDE INFORMATION ACROSS MULTIPLE SCIENTIFIC DOMAINS IN AGRICULTURE AND POWER TECHNOLOGY BREAKTHROUGHS THAT WILL INCREASE THE COMPETITIVENESS OF THE AMERICAN SPECIALTY CROP INDUSTRY. THE NEW EQUIPMENT WOULD BE UTILIZED BY FACULTY AND STUDENTS FOR EDUCATION AND RESEARCH, AND ALLOW US TO COLLABORATE WITH OTHER INSTITUTIONS ACROSS THE NATION NEEDING FIELD DATA TO VALIDATE REMOTE IMAGERY. OUR HOPE IS THAT THIS EQUIPMENT WOULD ALSO SERVE AS THE BASIS FOR A JOINT CENTER ON DATA ASSIMILATION FOR SPATIAL ANALYSIS OF SOILS AND CROP PERFORMANCE IN COLLABORATION WITH SCIENTISTS FROM NEIGHBORING UNIVERSITIES.

TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY-COMMERCE (TAMUC) WILL BUILD CAPACITY THROUGH A PLANNING ACTIVITY TO SUPPORT THE DEVELOPMENT OF SECONDARY LEVEL URBAN AGRICULTURAL EDUCATORS WITH ACADEMIC AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE AND FOOD SYSTEMS. THIS INITIATIVE WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER OF FANH GRADUATES AT TAMUC WITH THE SOCIAL, LEADERSHIP, AND TECHNICAL SKILLS NEEDED BY URBAN AGRICULTURAL EDUCATORS. THE ACTIVITY IS AFFILIATED WITH THE AGRICULTURE ACADEMY, A PARTNERSHIP WITH DALLAS COLLEGE (DC) TO INCREASE QUANTITY AND DIVERSITY OF BACHELOR'S DEGREE (BS) GRADUATES IN FANH. DALLAS COLLEGE PROVIDES THE FIRST TWO YEARS OF INSTRUCTION AND THE THIRD AND FOURTH YEARS WILL BE TAUGHT BY TAMUC, INCLUDING THE THIRD YEAR TAUGHT AT DALLAS COLLEGE BY FACULTY FROM TAMUC. PLANS ARE CURRENTLY UNDERWAY FOR THE AGRICULTURE ACADEMY TO BEGIN IN THE FALL OF 2021. EDUCATOR PREPARATION IN AGRICULTURE, FOOD, AND NATURAL RESOURCES FOR GRADES 6-12 IS THE PRIMARY FOCUS OF THIS INITIATIVE WHICH WILL STRENGTHEN EXISTING COURSES, PROVIDE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING FOR STUDENTS, AND EXPANDS RECRUITMENT AND MARKETING CAPABILITIES. THIS IS A PLANNING ACTIVITY WHICH WILL BEGIN IN JANUARY OF 2021 AND EXTEND THROUGH DECEMBER OF 2021.THIS EDUCATION PROJECT WILL FACILITATE STRATEGIC PLANNING SESSIONS TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES (1) IDENTIFY KEY STAKEHOLDERS AND OPINION LEADERS FOR URBAN AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION IN DALLAS COUNTY, (2) IDENTIFY POTENTIAL PUBLIC SCHOOL, AGENCY, INDUSTRY, AND NONPROFIT PARTNERS FOR RELEVANT EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, (3) DEVELOP AGREEMENTS FOR FIELD-BASED TEACHING INTERNSHIPS IN URBAN SETTINGS, (4) ESTABLISH SERVICE-ORIENTED EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, (5) DEVELOP A PROPOSAL FOR A SUBSEQUENT LARGE-SCALE COMPREHENSIVE INITIATIVE (LCI)

THIS PROJECT IMPROVES THE WELDING EQUIPMENT THROUGH THE PURCHASE OF EIGHT LINCOLN ELECTRIC C300 MULTIPROCESS WELDERS. THE C300 ALLOWS OUR STUDENTS TO LEARN HOW TO COMPLETE THE FOLLOWING WELDING PROCESSES: SHIELDED METAL ARC WELDING (SMAW), GAS METAL ARC WELDING (GMAW), GAS TUNGSTEN ARC WELDING (GTAW) AND FLUX CORE WELDING FROM ONE MACHINE. THE C300 WOULD REPLACE OUTDATED EQUIPMENT AND OFFER FOUR DIFFERENT PROCESSES IN ONE STATION. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WOULD INCLUDE THE PURCHASE OF TWO TORCHMATE 4400 PLASMA CUTTING TABLES. THE TXST DAS CURRENTLY DOES NOT HAVE AN OPERATIONAL CNC PLASMA CUTTING TABLE IN THE WELDING LABORATORY. THE TORCHMATE 4400 ALLOWS STUDENTS TO LEARN HOW TO USE COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN (CAD) SOFTWARE TO DESIGN ITEMS TO BE CUT USING A CNC PLASMA CUTTING TABLE. THE PURCHASE OF THESE MACHINES WOULD ALSO INCLUDE THE EDUCATIONAL SOFTWARE PACKAGES FOR COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN (CAD) AND COMPUTER AIDED MANUFACTURING (CAM). STUDENTS WILL USE CAD/CAM SOFTWARE, WHICH IS WIDELY UTILIZED IN INDUSTRY TO DESIGN AND DRAW PARTS. THEY WILL GAIN EXPERIENCE IN CREATING PARTS IN A CAD ENVIRONMENT, ENTERING SPECIFICATIONS, SETTING TOLERANCES, AND CHECKING TOOL PATHS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO UPDATE THE WELDING LABORATORY AT THE TXST DAS FOR THE AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION STUDENTS AND THE NEWLY TRANSITIONED AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS STUDENTS. THE PURPOSE WILL BE FULFILLED BY THE FOLLOWING OBJECTIVES: 1) PROVIDE WELDING TRAINING USING PROCESSES THAT MEET INDUSTRY STANDARDS, 2) PREPARE STUDENTS TO USE PRODUCT DESIGN AND RAPID PRODUCTION FABRICATION, AND 3) PURCHASE EQUIPMENT NEEDED TO CONDUCT VIRTUAL REALITY SEQUENCING RESEARCH.

THIS COLLABORATIVE EDUCATIONAL PROJECT BETWEEN ABRAHAM BALDWIN AGRICULTURAL COLLEGE (ABAC) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA VETERINARY DIAGNOSTIC LABORATORY (UGA VDL) WILL ENGAGE 50 BIOLOGY AND ANIMAL SCIENCE STUDENTS PER YEAR WITH EXPERIENCES AND OPPORTUNITIES IN VETERINARY MEDICINE. BOTH LOCATED IN TIFTON, GA, THE TWO INSTITUTIONS SERVE ONE OF THE MOST ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED, RURAL AREAS OF THE COUNTRY. TO MEET THE DEMAND FOR VETERINARIANS IN THESE AREAS, THE DISCIPLINE CODE A, B, V PROJECT WILL INCREASE THE NUMBER AND QUALITY OF VETERINARY MEDICINE APPLICANTS BY GIVING STUDENTS THE EXPERIENCE AND TRAINING THEY NEED TO BE SUCCESSFUL. OVER THE COURSE OF THE PROJECT, A TOTAL OF 150 ABAC STUDENTS WILL: (1) LEARN ABOUT VETERINARY SCIENCE APPLICATIONS THROUGH THEIR PARTICIPATION IN EXTRAMURAL CLUBS, MONTHLY SEMINARS, AND DAYLONG WORKSHOPS AT THE UGA VDL; (2) LEARN ABOUT VETERINARY SCIENCE TECHNIQUES AND THEORY THROUGH CREDIT-BEARING, UPPER DIVISION COURSES TAUGHT BY ABAC AND/OR THE UGA VDL FACULTY, UTILIZING THE RESOURCES, MATERIALS, AND EQUIPMENT AVAILABLE AT THE DIAGNOSTIC LAB; (3) DEEPEN THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF SCIENTIFIC METHODOLOGY AND ENHANCE THEIR RESEARCH SKILLS BY COMPLETING 14 WEEK, PARTTIME INTERNSHIPS DURING SPRING AND FALL SEMESTERS AND THROUGH EIGHT WEEK FULL-TIME SUMMER INTERNSHIPS, ALL UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF THE UGA VDL FACULTY MEMBERS, AND WILL; (4) DEVELOP RESEARCH DISSEMINATION AND PEER NETWORKING SKILLS BY PRESENTING INTERNSHIP RESULTS IN AT LEAST ONE LOCAL, REGIONAL, OR NATIONAL CONFERENCE. A SUCCESSFUL PROJECT CAN SERVE AS A MODEL FOR SIMILAR INSTITUTIONS NATIONWIDE. THE EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES OF THIS PROJECT ALIGN WITH NLCGA GOALS THROUGH TEACHING, OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, AND BY INCREASING THE NUMBER OF QUALIFIED GRADUATES FOR FUTURE EMPLOYMENT.

POLLINATORS HAVE SEEN MAJOR DECLINES IN RECENT DECADES. PESTICIDE EXPOSURE, PESTS, DISEASES, AND A SIGNIFICANT LOSS OF HABITAT DUE TO URBANIZATION HAVE PLAYED AN IMPORTANT ROLE IN THE LOSS OF POLLINATORS. LOSS OF HABITAT HAS BEEN EXACERBATED BY INCREASED DROUGHT BROUGHT ABOUT BY CLIMATE CHANGE. THE PLANT DRIPS (PLANT DROUGHT RESPONSE AND INSECT POLLINATOR STUDIES) PROJECT AT TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY-COMMERCE AND TARLETON STATE UNIVERSITY SEEKS TO LEARN HOW POLLINATOR-FRIENDLY PERENNIALS IN ORNAMENTAL LANDSCAPES PROVIDE A SOLUTION. THIS RESEARCH AND EDUCATION PROJECT LEVERAGES CURRENT A&M-COMMERCE AND TARLETON RESOURCES TO CREATE A RESEARCH AND EDUCATION GARDENS THAT ADDRESS QUESTIONS ABOUT THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MOISTURE STRESS, ORNAMENTAL PLANTS AND POLLINATORS, AND THE INTERRELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE THREE UNDER DISCIPLINE CODES P (PLANT SCIENCES AND HORTICULTURE), D (SOIL SCIENCES), AND T (ENTOMOLOGY - PLANT). WE WANT TO FIND PLANTS THAT WILL SURVIVE ON DRIPS OF WATER WHILE PROVIDING DRIPS OF NECTAR AND POLLEN FOR FORAGING POLLINATORS, ENHANCING BOTH THE AESTHETIC AND ECOLOGICAL ROLES OF OUR LANDSCAPES. THE PROJECT HAS THREE OBJECTIVES:1. EVALUATE LANDSCAPE PERENNIALS ACROSS MULTIPLE SOIL MOISTURE LEVELS,2. EVALUATE POLLINATOR BEHAVIORS RELATED TO FLORAL TIMING AND FLOWER QUALITY AND HOW THESE CHANGE DURING PERIODS OF WATER DEFICITS, AND3. CREATE DEMONSTRATION LANDSCAPES THAT IMPROVE INSTRUCTION AND EXPLORATION IN PLANT SCIENCE, SOIL SCIENCE, HORTICULTURE, ENTOMOLOGY, AND SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE EDUCATION AT A&M-COMMERCE AND TARLETON.THESE OBJECTIVES ARE BUILD EDUCATION AND RESEARCH CAPACITY AT A&M-COMMERCE AND TARLETON, MAINTAINING AND EXPANDING THE INSTITUTIONS' CAPACITY TO CONDUCT EDUCATIONAL AND RESEARCH ACTIVITIES.

CURRENTLY, THREE IS NO OFFICIAL METHOD FOR GOAT PROCESSING WITH SKIN, WHICH WOULD BE BENEFICIAL TO THE US GOAT INDUSTRY AND ETHNIC MEAT CONSUMERS. IN 2019, THE IMPORTED GOAT MEAT CONSTITUTED UP TO 65% OF DOMESTIC GOAT CONSUMPTION IN THE U.S. WITH 100% IMPORT OF SKIN-ON GOAT MEAT. THE SUCCESS OF THIS PROJECT WILL GENERATE ETHNIC (SKIN-ON) AND TRADITIONAL (SKIN-OFF) GOAT MEATS WITH QUALITY AND SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS AS WELL AS EDUCATION OF UNIVERSITY STUDENTS AND INDUSTRY EMPLOYEES FOR NON-TRADITIONAL MEAT PRODUCTS.TO ACHIEVE THIS GOAL, THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES ARE:                                                                     1.DEVELOP SKIN-ON GOAT PROCESSING FOR ETHNIC GOAT MEAT PRODUCTS.                                                   2.SYSTEMATICALLY GENERATE NON-TRADITIONAL MEAT FOR NICHE MARKETS AND TRADITIONAL MEAT FOR TRADITIONAL MARKETS WITH QUALITY AND SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS.                                                                                                3.PROVIDE COLLEGE STUDENTS AND INDUSTRY STAKEHOLDERS WITH EDUCATIONAL AND TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES IN MEAT PROCESSING.THE NUMBER ONE CHALLENGE IN THE GOAT MEAT INDUSTRY IS LOW PROFITABILITY AND TOUGH MEAT, PARTIALLY DUE TO A SKIN ELIMINATION BEFORE CARCASS CHILLING. SKIN REPRESENTS ABOUT 9% OF GOAT BODY WEIGHT AND SERVES AS A BARRIER TO MOISTURE LOSS AND COLD SHORTENING DURING CHILLING. IN THIS PROJECT, WE WILL DEVELOP SKIN-ON PROCESSING, IMPLEMENT THE TECHNOLOGY IN THE CURRENT ACADEMIC AND LABORATORY COURSES, AND TRANSFER THE KNOWLEDGE TO THE GOAT INDUSTRY THROUGH WORKSHOPS AND SEMINARS.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ANIMAL AND VETERINARY SCIENCES, HUNTLEY COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, NEEDED TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR CAREERS IN FEED MANUFACTURING OR RELATED FIELDS. THE DEPARTMENT AND COLLEGE ACCORD HIGH PRIORITY TO THE PROPOSED PROJECT BECAUSE OF ITS POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS WITH JOB READY SKILLS REQUIRED IN THE FEED MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY. THE NUMBER OF BACCALAUREATE DEGREE-HOLDERS JOINING THE FEED MANUFACTURING INDUSTRY IS SMALL WITH UNDERREPRESENTED GRADUATES SHOW AFFECTED THE MOST (U.S. CENSUS BUREAU, 2012). CAL POLY POMONA (CPP) PRIDES ITSELF AND IS PROVIDING QUALITY TEACHING PREMISED ON THE LEARN-BY-DOING MODEL, RESEARCH AND OUTREACH SERVICES TO CLIENTELE. SIXTEEN UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM SUMMER TRAINING OPPORTUNITIES INCLUDING FEEDING LIVESTOCK ON CPP FARM ON FEEDS PRODUCED IN THE FEED MILL. FURTHERMORE, THE PLACEMENT OF CPP GRADUATES IN COMPETITIVE POSITIONS IN THE FEEDMANUFACTURING INDUSTRY WILL ADD DIVERSITY TO AVAILABE CAREER OPPORTUNITIES AND POSITIVELY IMPACT RECRUITMENT. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE: (I) ENHANCE THE SKILL SET OF SIXTEEN UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN FEED MANUFACTURING TECHNOLOGY; (II) DEVELOP A MINOR IN FEED MANUFACTURING TECHNOLOGY; AND (III) RESEARCH FEED ADDITIVES FOR NUTRITIONAL AND MEDICINAL PROPERTIES BENEFICIAL TO CHICKENS. THIS PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE GOAL OF USDA NIFA-NLGCA FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 2020: FOCUS ON DEVELOPING THE NEXT GENERATION OF RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES.
BUILDING A REGIONAL SOIL HEALTH INITIATIVE

THE CENTRAL VALLEY OF CALIFORNIA IS ONE OF THE WORLD'S MOST PRODUCTIVE AGRICULTURAL REGIONS AND MOST COUNTIES IN THE VALLEY (E.G. TULARE, KERN) ARE THE NATION'S TOP AGRICULTURE PRODUCING COUNTIES. THE VALLEY'S TOP AGRICULTURE COMMODITIES ARE DAIRY AND CROP PRODUCTS. ACCORDINGLY, A HUGE AMOUNT OF AGRICULTURE-DERIVED WASTE STREAMS SUCH AS DAIRY WASTEWATER AND ORCHARD PRUNING ARE GENERATED. THEREFORE, THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT BETWEEN CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY-BAKERSFIELD (CSUB) AND THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA-RIVERSIDE (UCR) IS TO BUILD THE CAPACITY FOR FANH PROGRAM STUDENTS, WOMEN, AND UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITIES IN INVESTIGATING SUSTAINABLE WASTE TREATMENT METHODS AND DEVELOPING SUSTAINABLE ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND LEADERSHIP THROUGH INTEGRATED RESEARCH/EDUCATION/OUTREACH/EXTENSION. TWO RESEARCH LABORATORIES, ONE ENTREPRENEURSHIP CLUB, AND THREE RESEARCH CENTERS WILL COLLABORATE TO ACHIEVE SIX SUPPORTING OBJECTIVES: 1) DEVELOP STUDENT HANDS-ON SKILLS VIA EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN ASSESSING AN ADVANCED THERMOCHEMICAL CONVERSION TECHNOLOGY AND A POLYMER COMPOSITE FABRICATION METHOD FOR ENERGY/RESOURCE RECOVERY FROM AGRICULTURAL WASTES (10 STUDENTS); 2) DEVELOP STUDENT COMPUTATIONAL AND ANALYTICAL CAPABILITIES IN MODELING WASTE-TO-ENERGY PROCESS AND ASSESSING AGRICULTURAL WASTE AVAILABILITY AND PROCESS FEASIBILITY (4 STUDENTS); 3) CONDUCT OUTREACH WITH THE VALLEY COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING INTERNSHIPS AND BUILD NEW STARTUPS (~66 STUDENTS); 4) DELIVER CLASSES AND WORKSHOPS ON SUSTAINABLE ENTREPRENEURSHIP AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS DEVELOPMENT (~470 STUDENTS); 5) DEVELOP CURRICULUM MATERIALS FOR THE ENVIRONMENTAL ENGINEERING LECTURE AND TEACHING LABORATORY, AGRICULTURAL BUSINESS CLASSES, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, AND 6) ENRICH EXTENSION ACTIVITIES THROUGH VISITING AGRICULTURAL WASTE TREATMENT PROJECTS AND DISSEMINATE INFORMATION. MOREOVER, A CSUB-UC PIPELINE WILL BE ESTABLISHED FOR PREPARING CSUB STUDENTS TO PURSUE GRADUATEDEGREES.

THE CENTER FOR REGENERATIVE AGRICULTURE AND RESILIENT SYSTEMS (CRARS)AT CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, CHICO (CHICO STATE), IN COLLABORATION WITH THECALIFORNIA ASSOCIATION OF RESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICTS (CARCD), PROPOSES TO CREATE THEAGRICULTURAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS LEARNING COLLABORATIVE (AMS COLLABORATIVE) TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND ENHANCE IMPLEMENTATION SUPPORT FOR THE EXPANSION OF SYSTEMS-BASED FARM/RANCH/FOREST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IN NORTHERN CALIFORNIA PRODUCTION SYSTEMS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL LAY THE FOUNDATION FOR ONGOING, SUSTAINABLE DEVELOPMENT THAT WILL CONTINUE TO ADDRESS IDENTIFIED STAKEHOLDER NEEDS, AS WELL AS OUR LONG-TERM GOALS TO BUILD ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT CAPACITY IN SYSTEMS-BASED AGRICULTURAL MANAGEMENT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE RESPONSIVE TO THE RESULTS OF A BROADLY DISSEMINATED NEEDS ASSESSMENT (113 RESPONSES ANALYZED). OUR STAKEHOLDERS INCLUDE PRODUCERS; AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS, INCLUDING COOPERATIVE EXTENSION, CALIFORNIARESOURCE CONSERVATION DISTRICT (RCD), AND NRCS STAFF; AND STUDENTS ENROLLED IN AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES, AND LAND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT.      PROJECT GOALS:1)ESTABLISH FLEXIBLE NON-CREDIT BEARING LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO ADDRESS A BROAD RANGE OF STAKEHOLDER NEEDS AND INTERESTS;2)ESTABLISH A COHORT OF PEER MENTORS/ROLE MODELS IN SYSTEMS-BASED AGRICULTURAL MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS; AND3)PROVIDE ADDITIONAL PARTICIPANT-DRIVEN SUPPORT MECHANISMS TO PROMOTE AND ENCOURAGE SUSTAINED KNOWLEDGE BUILDING/SHARING AND CONNECTIONS ACROSS THE COMMUNITY.       PROJECT OBJECTIVES:1)DEVELOP FOUR ONLINE COURSES IN AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS AND SOIL HEALTH MANAGEMENT THAT WILL SERVE AS A FOUNDATION FOR MULTIPLE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH PATHWAYS;2)IDENTIFY, SUPPORT, AND ASSESS THE EXPERIENCES OF 10 PAIRED TEAMS OF NORTHERN CALIFORNIA PRODUCERS AND RCD TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE PROVIDERS WHO WILL SERVE AS PEER ROLE MODELS AND MENTORS; AND3)ADD VALUE TO EXISTING CRARS OUTREACH AND ASSISTANCE EFFORTS THROUGH COMMUNITY-DRIVEN WORKSHOPS AND AND AN ONLINE AMS COLLABORATIVE NETWORK.        PROJECT OUTCOMES:1)FOUR ON-LINE COURSES IN SYSTEMS-BASED AGRICULTURE,2)A SUSTAINED PRESENTATION SESSION AT THE CARCD ANNUAL CONFERENCE,3)SUSTAINED VALUE-ADDED ELEMENTS TO CRARS OUTREACH EFFORTS; AND4)DATA-INFORMED (QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE) APPROACHES AND LESSONS LEARNED THAT CAN BE TRANSLATED TO OTHER LOCAL AND REGIONAL CONTEXTS. OVER TIME, WE CAN ADDITIONALLY EXPECT INCREASED LITERACY IN SYSTEMS-BASED AGRICULTURE AT CSU, CHICO.      MEDIUM- AND LONG-TERM OUTCOMESOF THE AMS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT BEYOND THE FUNDING PERIOD INCLUDE:1)ESTABLISH A PROFESSIONAL COURSE SERIES AS A CONTINUING PROGRAM FOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS AND PROFESSIONALS,2)CREATE AN INSTITUTIONALLY-APPROVAL 21-CREDIT CERTIFICATE PROGRAM AVAILABLE TO REGIONAL AND NATIONAL AUDIENCES;3)ESTABLISH AN UNDERGRADUATE PROGRAM AND ONLINE MASTER'S PROGRAM IN SYSTEMS-BASED AGRICULTURAL MANAGEMENT; AND4)SUSTAIN THE AMS COLLABORATIVE THROUGH CONTINUING PARTNERSHIPS, COLLABORATIONS AND PROJECTS.

THE GOAL OF THIS JOINT EDUCATION PROJECT IS TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF STUDENTS FROM TRADITIONALLY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES TRANSFERRING FROM REGIONAL COMMUNITY COLLEGES TO NMHU AND GRADUATING WITH LEADERSHIP AND RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IN NATURAL RESOURCES MANAGEMENT THROUGH ENGAGEMENT IN THE RIO MORA NATURAL RESOURCES FIELD SKILLS & LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM. THE PROJECT WILL BUILD LASTING RELATIONSHIPS WITH THREE REGIONAL HISPANIC-SERVING COMMUNITY COLLEGES, LUNA COMMUNITY COLLEGE (LCC), SANTA FE COMMUNITY COLLEGE (SFCC) AND THE COMMUNITY COLLEGE OF DENVER (CCD) THAT SUPPORT THE TRANSFER OF NATURAL RESOURCE STUDENTS BY INCORPORATING CROSS-INSTITUTIONAL PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT FOR ALL PARTICIPATING FACULTY WITH A TEAM-TEACHING MODEL THROUGHOUT THE PROJECT.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS INTEGRATED PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR FORAGE AND ANIMAL SCIENCE (A AND P CODES) PROGRAMS THROUGH THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A FUNCTIONAL FORAGE NUTRITION LABORATORY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE AT MARTIN IN COLLABORATION WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF MISSOURI. THIS ACCOMPLISHES SUPPORTING OBJECTIVES TO STRENGTHEN UG TEACHING TO ENHANCE STUDENT LEARNING, INCREASE YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN AGRICULTURE AND, SUPPORT LIVESTOCK COMMUNITIES IN DEVELOPING SUMMER FORAGE MANAGEMENT SKILLS THROUGH RESEARCH AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. WITH ASSISTANCE FROM AN ESTABLISHED FORAGE SCIENCE PROGRAM, THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE ABILITY OF A REGIONAL AGRICULTURAL UNIVERSITY TO INITIATE INNOVATIVE EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH PROGRAMS AND, CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR FUTURE COLLABORATION WITH OTHER INSTITUTES IN FORAGE SCIENCE.PLANS FOR THE PROJECT INCLUDE DEVELOPING THE INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE PROPOSED FORAGE LABORATORY, DESIGNING THE CORRESPONDING LABORATORY CURRICULUM, AND CREATING A PLATFORM FOR PARTICIPATION AND LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STAKEHOLDERS.UNDER EDUCATION, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED AREAS OF CURRICULUM DESIGN, INSTRUCTION DELIVERY SYSTEMS, SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTATION FOR EDUCATION AND, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING. UNDER OUTREACH, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED AREAS OF 4-H ACTIVITY AND FANH SCIENCES. UNDER RESEARCH, THIS PROJECT ADDRESSES THE NEED AREA APPLIED STUDIES IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES.AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, UG STUDENTS WILL BETTER UNDERSTAND RESEARCH PROCEDURES AND IMPROVE ANALYTICAL SKILLS; FACULTY MEMBERS WILL HAVE OPPORTUNITIES TO IMPROVE RESEARCH, TEACHING, AND MENTORING SKILLS; LIVESTOCK PRODUCERS WILL BE INFORMED AND EDUCATED ON ALTERNATIVE FORAGE SPECIES FOR SUMMER FORAGE PRODUCTION AND; YOUTH PARTICIPATION IN AGRICULTURE AND LIVESTOCK PRODUCTION WILL BE ENHANCED.

AGRICULTURE IN THE SOUTHEASTERN UNITED STATES FACES MANY CHALLENGES IN THE COMING DECADES. THE ABILITY OF FARMERS, RANCHERS, AND FORESTERS TO COMPETE IN A HARSH ECONOMIC ENVIRONMENT IS BEING MADE INCREASINGLY DIFFICULT BY INVASIVE SPECIES, SOIL DEGRADATION, UNPREDICTABLE CLIMATES, AND OTHER ISSUES. TO ASSIST OUR REGIONAL PRODUCERS, WE PROPOSE PARTNERS FOR AGRICULTURAL INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABILITY (PAIS 2.0), THE GOAL OF WHICH WILL BE TO PROVIDE NEEDED OUTREACH AND ASSISTANCE TO STAKEHOLDERS IN THE WEST ALABAMA/EAST MISSISSIPPI REGION. WE WILL ACHIEVE THIS GOAL THROUGH 1) DEVELOPING A DATABASE OF STAKEHOLDER AWARENESS, 2) CREATING AN OUTREACH PROGRAM TO ADDRESS INFORMATION GAPS, 3) PROVIDING HANDS-ON ASSISTANCE IN THE FORM OF TRAINED STUDENT INTERNS, 4) ENHANCING CAREER OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS INTERESTED IN AGRICULTURE AND CONSERVATION, AND 5) CONTINUING THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE WEST ALABAMA CENTER FOR AGRICULTURE AND BIODIVERSITY.PAIS 2.0 WILL FOCUS ON FOUR SPECIFIC ISSUES AFFECTINGPRODUCTION IN THE REGION: 1) INVASIVE SPECIES, 2) POLLINATOR SUPPORT, 3) FOREST MANAGEMENT, AND 4) SOIL HEALTH. PAIS 2.0 IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT BETWEEN THE UNIVERSITY OF WEST ALABAMA (UWA), COASTAL ALABAMA COMMUNITY COLLEGE (CACC), EAST MISSISSIPPI COMMUNITY COLLEGE (EMCC), AND THE SUMTER COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT (SCSWCD), ALL OF WHICH SERVE THE RURAL BLACK BELT OF SOUTHWEST ALABAMA AND EASTERN MISSISSIPPI.PAIS 2.0 WILL STIMULATE INTERACTION BETWEEN STRUGGLING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS IN THE REGION AND THE INSTITUTIONS PREPARED TO ASSIST THEM. IN THIS WAY, IT WILL PROVIDE A COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE TO STAKEHOLDERS, SPUR ECONOMIC GROWTH, AND STABILIZE COMMUNITIES IN THE AREA.

MEETING THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR AGRICULTURAL COMMODITIES FOR FOOD, FEED, FUEL AND OTHER USES, WITHOUT PUTTING GREATER PRESSURE ON THE WORLD'S NATURAL RESOURCES, WILL REQUIRE INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS GENERATED BY THE NEXT GENERATION OF DIVERSE AND WELL-TRAINED SCIENTISTS IN FOOD, AGRICULTURAL, NATURAL RESOURCES AND HUMAN (FANH) SCIENCES. DESPITE THIS GROWING DEMAND FOR A SKILLED WORKFORCE, UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION REMAIN MAJOR CHALLENGES FOR INSTITUTIONS OF HIGHER EDUCATION, AS WELL AS FOR THE AGRICULTURAL AND FOOD INDUSTRY. THESE CHALLENGES ARE EXACERBATED FOR LOW-INCOME, FIRST-GENERATION, AND TRADITIONALLY UNDERREPRESENTED MINORITY (URM) STUDENTS WHO GENERALLY LACK STRONG NETWORKS AND CONNECTIONS TO FACULTY AND MENTORS THAT WOULD INCREASE THEIR SUCCESS, PARTICULARLY IN STEM COURSES AND RESEARCH EXPERIENCES. HERE, WE PROPOSE TO DEVELOP A PROGRAM TO ENHANCE CURRENT PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY MONTEREY BAY (CSUMB) AND HARTNELL COLLEGE (HC), TWO HISPANIC SERVING INSTITUTIONS LOCATED IN MONTEREY COUNTY, CALIFORNIA, AN AREA POPULARLY REFERRED AS THE SALAD BOWL OF THE WORLD, AND EQUALLY KNOWN FOR HAVING ONE OF THE WIDEST INCOME DISPARITIES BETWEEN HISPANIC AND WHITE POPULATIONS. THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO ADVANCE EDUCATIONAL ACHIEVEMENT AND ENTHUSIASM FOR FANH FIELDS, PROMOTING THE TRANSFER PROCESS FROM HC TO CSUMB, AND TO IMPROVE SOCIAL MOBILITY BY PREPARING REGIONAL STUDENTS FOR CAREERS IN THE AGRICULTURAL SECTOR. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE STUDENT-LEARNING THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF COURSE-BASED UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH EXPERIENCES IN THE CLASSROOM, AIMED AT ENHANCING PROFESSIONAL AND ACADEMIC GROWTH OF PARTICIPATING STUDENTS, AS WELL AS THEIR ABILITY TO IDENTIFY THEMSELVES AS POTENTIAL ACTIVE PARTICIPANT OF THE SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH COMMUNITY WORKING TO ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES EXPERIENCED BY THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY. THESE COURSE-BASED RESEARCH EXPERIENCES WILL ALSO ENHANCE EARLY PARTICIPATION AND EXPOSURETO INTERDISCIPLINARY LABORATORY AND FIELD-BASED RESEARCH OFFERING AUTHENTIC EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMMUNITY COLLEGE AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS TO IMPROVE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH AND MODERN MICROBIAL BIOTECHNOLOGY RESEARCH APPROACHES, INCLUDING MOLECULAR DIAGNOSTICS OF SOILBORNE PATHOGENS, AS WELL AS UNDERSTANDING OF THE COMPLEX ISSUES SURROUNDING PLANT DISEASE MANAGEMENT. COLLECTIVELY, THESE EFFORTS WILL CONTRIBUTE TO EMPOWER URM STUDENTS AT HISPANIC SERVING INSTITUTIONS TO BECOME THE NEXT GENERATION OF AGRICULTURAL PROFESSIONALS THAT WILL FILL THE LARGE AND GROWING NUMBER OF AGRICULTURAL JOBS IN OUR REGION AND STATE. PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES AND THE ORGANIZATION OF A REGIONAL CAREER FAIR WILL ALLOW STUDENTS FROM THE TRI-COUNTY REGION TO MEET WITH PRIVATE ORGANIZATIONS AND FEDERAL AGENCIES TO EXPLORE CAREERS AND PROFESSIONAL RESOURCES, AND TO BECOME AWARE OF RELEVANT JOB OPENINGS, INTERNSHIPS, AND SCHOLARSHIPS. ULTIMATELY, THE MISSION-ORIENTED RESEARCH PROPOSED IN THIS PROJECT FOCUSING ON CHARACTERIZING INDIGENOUSSOIL BACTERIAL POPULATIONS FROM ADAPTED TO LOCAL AGRICULTURAL ENVIRONMENTS AND CATALOGUING THEIR ANTIMICROBIAL CAPACITIES AND BIOCONTROL POTENTIAL AGAINST PLANT PATHOGENS OF LOCALLY-GROWN CROPS IS AIMED AT ADDRESSING REAL-WORLD PROBLEMS, AND SPECIFICALLY, TO ENHANCE UNDERSTANDING OF THE DIVERSITY AND FUNCTION OF INDIGENOUS SOIL MICROBIAL COMMUNITIES, AND THEIR POTENTIAL APPLICATIONS TO PROMOTE SOIL HEALTH AND AGRICULTURAL SUSTAINABILITY.

THIS PROJECT IS AIMED AT PURCHASING SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT TO BUILD A FERMENTED BEVERAGES ANALYSIS LABORATORY TO ENHANCE LEARN BY DOING, PRACTICAL TRAINING, AND RESEARCH IN FERMENTED FOODS AT CALIFORNIA POLYTECHNIC STATE UNIVERSITY (CAL POLY). THE EQUIPMENT WILL ALLOW FOR THE ANALYSIS OF QUALITY PARAMETERS ROUTINELY MEASURED IN THE INDUSTRY TO MONITOR FERMENTED BEVERAGE PRODUCTION. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, NEW FERMENTATION TEACHING MODULES WILL BE DEVELOPED, AND BOTH THE EQUIPMENT AND NEW TEACHING MODULES WILL BE INCORPORATED INTO EXISTING COURSES. THIS PROJECT FURTHER SEEKS TO UTILIZE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AS THE MAIN PEDAGOGICAL TECHNIQUE FOR INTEGRATING FERMENTATION TOPICS INTO THE CURRICULUM. THIS IS AN EDUCATION GRANT WHICH COVERS THE RELATED BIOLOGICAL SCIENCES AND FOOD SCIENCE/TECHNOLOGY AND MANUFACTURING DISCIPLINES. THE NEWLY DEVELOPED LABORATORY WILL SERVE AS A MAJOR RESOURCE TO PROVIDE RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES FOR BOTH UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS THE EDUCATION NEEDS OF PROVIDING SCIENTIFIC INSTRUMENTATION FOR EDUCATION AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND WILL HELP PREPARE STUDENTS FOR GRADUATE SCHOOL OR FOR CAREERS IN THE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY. IT ALSO ALIGNS WELL WITH THE PURPOSE AND PRIORITIES OF THE NLGCA PROGRAM, WHICH ARE TO MAINTAIN AND EXPAND CAPACITY TO CONDUCT EDUCATION, RESEARCH, AND OUTREACH/EXTENSION ACTIVITIES RELATED TO THE FANH SCIENCES.

WE PROPOSE A PROJECT THAT PUTS US AT THE FOREFRONT OF ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT BRANCHES OFAGRICULTURAL CHEMISTRY: USING ENZYMES TO DEVELOP AND MODIFY A BIOSENSOR FOR DIABETES. IMPORTANTLY,THESE ENZYMES ARE MANUFACTURED IN A CORN KERNEL BIOFACTORY. OUR PROJECT SUPPORTS THE NATIONALINSTITUTE OF FOOD AND AGRICULTURE (NIFA) GOAL TO ADVANCE OUR NATION'S ABILITY TO STRENGTHEN HIGHEREDUCATION IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. THIS PROJECT ALSO SUPPORTS THE USDA RESEARCH,EDUCATION AND ECONOMICS (REE) GOAL OF SUSTAINABLE INTENSIFICATION OF AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION,NANOTECHNOLOGY, AND BIOTECHNOLOGY. THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN INFRASTRUCTURE THAT SUPPORTSRESEARCH CAPABILITIES AT ARKANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY (A-STATE) TO ESTABLISH GREATER CREDIBILITY INPRODUCTIVITY FROM RESEARCH FUNDING, PARTICULARLY IN THE AREA OF NANOTECHNOLOGY AND BIOTECHNOLOGY,WHICH WILL INCREASE THE CAPABILITY OF A-STATE TO BE MORE COMPETITIVE FOR FEDERAL FUNDS FOR RESEARCH.AGRICULTURAL CHEMISTRY, WHICH INVOLVES CHANGES IN THE PRODUCTION AND OPTIMAL USE OF CROPS, IS ANAPPLIED SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY. THE PROJECT ALSO IS FOCUSED ON INCREASING THE NUMBER OF MINORITIESAND WOMEN IN STEM FOR AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH THROUGH UNDERGRADUATE OPPORTUNITIES. THE LONG-TERMGOAL OF THIS RESEARCH PROJECT IS MINIATURIZATION OF A SIGNIFICANTLY IMPROVED GLUCOSE BIOSENSOR THATHAS INCREASED SENSITIVITY AND LONGEVITY FOR DIABETES SUFFERERS. THIS GOAL IS DEPENDENT ON USINGENZYMES PRODUCED FROM AN AGRICULTURAL CROP.

GIVEN THE IMPORTANCE OF SUSTAINABLE FORAGE CROP PRODUCTION, INCREASING SOIL HEALTH, AND GROWING DEMAND FOR QUALIFIED NEW PROFESSIONALS PREPARED IN THESE AREAS, THE DEVELOPMENT OF PROFESSIONALS IN FORAGES, GRAZING MANAGEMENT, AND SOIL HEALTH ASSESSMENTS HAVE BECOME MORE ESSENTIAL THAN EVER.IMPROVING CROP ALTERNATIVE OPTIONS IS CRITICAL FOR A STRONG AGRICULTURAL ECONOMY (MARQUES ET AL., 2020). WITH INCREASING EXTREME CLIMATE EVENTS LEADING TO DROUGHT AND FORAGE CROP WINTER-KILL, WELL-INFORMED ADJUSTMENTS TO CROP PRODUCTION MANAGEMENT ARE NEEDED.THIS PROPOSAL IS A SYNERGY BETWEEN STUDENT TRAINING, EXTENSION EFFORTS, AND EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO WATERSHED PRODUCERS INTERESTED IN APPLIED FIELD RESEARCH ON ALTERNATIVE FORAGE CROPS AND SUMMER ANNUAL FORAGES USING FIELD INSTRUMENTATION FOR MONITORING FORAGES (CANOPY ANALYZER) AND SOIL HEALTH (HANDHELD TIME DOMAIN REFLECTOMETERS). THESE PORTABLE INSTRUMENTS WILL ALSO ALLOW INSTRUCTORS TO CONDUCT FIELD-LABORATORY EXERCISES, AND EXTENSION TRAINING IN THE AREA OF PLANT-SOIL INTERFACE WITH APPLICATIONS IN FORAGE AND CROP PRODUCTION, GRAZING MANAGEMENT, AND SOIL HEALTH. RESULTS ON FORAGE AND SOIL TESTING WILL ALSO BE MADE AVAILABLE TO FARMERS TO DEMONSTRATE SUSTAINABLE PRODUCTION METHODS THAT HAVE MINIMUM IMPACT ON THE ENVIRONMENT.

THROUGH ONGOING, ITERATIVE DISCUSSIONS BETWEEN UNIVERSITYOF WI-PLATTEVILLE AND THE AMERICAN INDIAN HIGHER EDUCATION CONSORTIUM (AIHEC), WE HAVE DISCOVERED MANY AREAS OF COMPLEMENTARY AND SYNERGISTIC RESEARCH AND EDUCATION RELATING TO THE TOPICS OF SOIL AND WATER QUALITY. THIS HAS GIVEN RISE TO A DESIRE TO IDENTIFY THE LARGER SCOPE OF POTENTIAL COLLABORATION AMONG THESE INSTITUTIONS AND CREATE A COLLABORATIVE NETWORK ACROSS SITES TO FACILITATE RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES. WHILE WE FEEL THAT THERE ARE SIGNIFICANT RESEARCH NETWORKS WITHIN THE LAND GRANT UNIVERSITIES AND STATE AND FEDERAL GOVERNMENTS THIS CAPACITY IS UNDERUTILIZED IN NON-LAND GRANT COLLEGES AND THE TRIBAL COLLEGES AND UNIVERSITIES. HERE WE PROPOSE TO ENHANCE OUR CAPACITY FOR RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH BY DEVELOPING A MUTUALLY BENEFICIAL NETWORK OF SCIENTISTS AND EDUCATORS TO LEVERAGE EXISTING RESOURCES, SHARE PERSPECTIVES, AND BUILD CAPACITY TO SUPPORT SUSTAINABLE INTENSIFICATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES.THROUGH THIS PLANNING GRANT WE INTEND TO RECRUIT ADDITIONAL INTERESTED SCIENTISTS AND EDUCATORS FROM INSTITUTIONS WITHIN AIHEC AND NLGCA IN ORDER TO ENGAGE IN INTER-INSTITUTIONAL STRATEGIC PLANNING WHICH WILL (1) IDENTIFY WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH CHALLENGES COMMON ACROSS THE NETWORK; (2) INVENTORY RELEVANT RESOURCES AND FACILITIES; (3) FORMULATE POTENTIAL COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND OUTREACH ACTIVITIES; AND (4) GENERATE AND IMPLEMENT A NLGCA LARGE-SCALE COMPREHENSIVE INITIATIVE GRANT PROPOSAL FOCUSED ON WATER QUALITY AND SOIL HEALTH.

TEXAS DAIRY INDUSTRY IS RAPIDLY EXPANDING. LOCATED AT THE HEART OF TEXAS MILKSHED, THE SOUTHWEST REGIONAL DAIRY CENTER (SWRDC) LOCATED AT TARLETON STATE UNIVERSITY IS AT THE FOREFRONT OF GATHERING AND PROCESSING RESEARCH-BASED INFORMATION FOR TEXAS DAIRY FARMERS. TO MEET THE SERVICE/OUTREACH DEMAND OF DAIRY COMMUNITIES OF ENTIRE TEXAS AND THE SOUTHWEST, IT BECAME APPARENT THAT THE SWRDC NEEDS GREATER CAPACITY FOR ENGAGING MORE GEOGRAPHICALLY DISTANT GROUPS, INCLUDING DAIRY PRODUCERS IN TEXAS PANHANDLES MILKSHED, AGRICULTURAL RESEARCHERS IN COLLEGE STATION, AND EXTENSION EDUCATORS SPREAD THROUGHOUT ALL TEXAS COUNTIES. TO ADDRESS THIS BOTTLENECK ISSUE, WE PROPOSE TO EMPLOY 360&DEG; VIRTUAL REALITY (VR) OUTREACHING OUTLET.THE PI'S ON THE PROJECT WILL RECORD VR VIDEOS IN DIFFERENT AREAS OF FARM AND MANURE MANAGEMENT. WE WILL USE THESE VR VIDEOS TO ENGAGE MORE PRODUCERS THROUGH THE STATE OF TX AND REACH MORE PERSONNEL THROUGH VR TRAINING. LASTLY, WE WILL DEVELOP AN EXTENSION TRAINING NETWORK THROUGH THE SWRDC TO TRAIN MORE PRODUCERS ON BEST PRACTICES.

THE UNITEDSTATES(U.S.)AGRICULTUREWORKFORCEIS INCREASINGLYDIVERSEINLANGUAGE,CULTURE,ANDEDUCATION.IMMIGRATION LABORISCRITICALTO PRODUCTIONAGRICULTURE AND SUSTAINABILITY, ASAPPROXIMATELYHALF OFALLFARMLABORERSAREHISPANIC.A LINGUISTICALLY DIVERSE WORKFORCE MAKES IT CHALLENGING FOR VETERINARIANS AND ANSC PROFESSIONALS TO COMMUNICATE EFFECTIVELY WITH NON-ENGLISH SPEAKING ANIMAL CARETAKERS, LEADING TO NEGATIVE IMPACTS ON ANIMAL HEALTH, WELFARE, AND FOOD SAFETY.OUR JOINT EFFORT PROPOSES TO MEDIATE THE POTENTIAL CULTURAL AND LANGUAGE BARRIER WITH ANIMAL CARETAKERS AND TO SUPPORTHIGHER EDUCATION IN FOOD,AGRICULTURE,NATURAL RESOURCES, ANDHUMAN SCIENCES (FANH). TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY (TTU), TARLETON STATE UNIVERSITY (TSU), NORTH CAROLINA STATE UNIVERSITY (NCSU), AND THE UNIVERSIDAD NACIONAL AUTONOMA DE MEXICO (UNAM) PROPOSETO1) DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT THREE COURSES (BEGINNER, LOWER-INTERMEDIATE AND HIGH-INTERMEDIATE) OF SPANISH FOR SPECIFIC PURPOSES IN AGRICULTURE (SSPA) IN THE FRAMEWORK OF THE CURRENT VETERINARY MEDICINE AND ANSC PROGRAM CURRICULUM USING INNOVATIVE TEACHING METHODSTHAT ENHANCE STUDENTS' METACOGNITIVE PROCESSESAND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNINGACTIVITIES INTEGRATED INTO THE CURRICULUM,AND 2) IMPROVE VETERINARY AND ANSC STUDENTS' COMMUNICATION ON-FARM WITH ANIMAL CARETAKERS, LEADING TO ENHANCED ANIMAL HEALTH, WELFARE, AND FOOD SAFETY.THE CURRICULA WILL BE EVALUATED (THROUGH A NEEDS ANALYSIS, STUDENT, AND ON-FARM SURVEYS, AND THE IMPACT OF THE PROGRAM THROUGH ON-FARM AUDITS BEFORE AND AFTER STUDENT PARTICIPATION), REFINED, AND DISSEMINATED. PRODUCTS GENERATED WILL INCLUDE SSPA CURRICULA COMPONENTS, AND HIGHLY QUALIFIED VETERINARY AND ANSC STUDENTS. THE BENEFITS OF THIS PROJECT WILL GO BEYOND THE LIFE OF THE GRANT AS A MODEL FOR OTHER NON-LAND GRANT INSTITUTIONS.

HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT (HWC) IS A TOPIC OF TREMENDOUS CONCERN FOR PEOPLE ALL OVER THE WORLD. IN NORTH AMERICA, CONFLICTS BETWEEN AGRICULTURAL PRODUCERS AND CARNIVORES SUCH AS GREY WOLVES, BEARS, AND COYOTES POSE SIGNIFICANT CHALLENGES TO BOTH PRODUCERS AS WELL AS STATE AND FEDERAL AGENCIES. AFRICAN COMMUNITIES ARE FREQUENTLY ON THE FOREFRONT OF HWC ISSUES, GIVEN A RAPIDLY EXPANDING HUMAN POPULATION AND INCREASING AGRICULTURAL DEVELOPMENT IN RURAL AREAS. THESE AREAS OF CONFLICT OFTEN ARE THE SITE OF SOME OF THE LARGEST REMAINING WILD POPULATIONS OF MANY SPECIES. IN BOTSWANA, "CONFLICT" TYPICALLY COMES IN THE FORM OF PREDATORS, LIKE LIONS, CHEETAHS, OR WILD DOGS, KILLING LIVESTOCK. MUCH OF THE RESEARCH AND PRACTICE ON HWC IS FOCUSED ON ALLEVIATING CONFLICT AND FINDING WAYS TO COMPENSATE PEOPLE WHO HAVE EXPERIENCED NEGATIVE INTERACTIONS WITH WILDLIFE. IN MORE RECENT YEARS, THE CONCERN HAS SHIFTED TO FINDING WAYS FOR PEOPLE AND WILD ANIMALS TO COEXIST, TO SHARE LANDSCAPES AND COMMUNITIES, EVEN AS THEY ARE COMPETING FOR SPACE, WATER, AND FOOD. THIS HOLISTIC APPROACH ACKNOWLEDGES THE SOCIAL AND HUMAN DIMENSIONS OF HWC. THIS APPROACH ALSO RECOGNIZES THAT CONFLICTS OVER LAND, POLITICS, VALUES, COMPETING LIVELIHOODS, AND OTHER SOCIAL TENSIONS, OR "HUMAN-HUMAN CONFLICTS," ARE AT THE ROOT OF HWC.A SIGNIFICANT BODY OF EVIDENCE ATTESTS TO THE IMPORTANCE OF EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN AUGMENTING TRADITIONAL CLASSROOM-BASED CURRICULUM. IMMERSIVE EXPERIENCES FACILITATE LEARNING BY PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO PROCESS AND TRANSFORM RELEVANT EXPERIENCES INTO KNOWLEDGE. SUCH "HANDS-ON" EXPERIENCES BENEFIT NATURAL RESOURCES STUDENTS BY FOSTERING THE ACQUISITION OF PRACTICAL KNOWLEDGE AND INCREASING STUDENT PERCEPTIONS OF THE APPLICABILITY OF BOTH FIELD-BASED AND CLASSROOM INFORMATION TO "REAL WORLD" SITUATIONS. THESE EXPERIENCES ALSO BENEFIT STUDENTS BY INSTILLING SOCIAL RESPONSIBILITY, PROMOTING INCLUSION OF HISTORICALLY UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS, AND "CEMENTING THEIR IDENTITYAS ECOLOGISTS". IN ASSESSING THE OUTLOOK FOR THE FISHERIES AND WILDLIFE PROFESSION IN THE COMING DECADES, EDGE (2016) ARGUED THAT UNIVERSITY NATURAL RESOURCES CURRICULA SHOULD INCLUDE A VARIETY OF EXPERIENTIAL-LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES - INCLUDING INTERNSHIPS, UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH, AND INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCES - IN ORDER TO PROVIDE GRADUATES THE APPROPRIATE SKILLS TO SUCCESSFUL ADDRESS NATURAL RESOURCE CHALLENGES. INTERNATIONAL EXPERIENCES ARE VALUABLE TOOLS FOR EXPOSING NATURAL RESOURCES STUDENTS TO ALTERNATIVE PROBLEM-SOLVING APPROACHES. BECAUSE INDIVIDUAL ATTITUDES TOWARD NATURE ARE DETERMINED LARGELY BY THE CULTURAL CONTEXT, ATTITUDES AND APPROACHES TOWARD WILDLIFE CONSERVATION ARE CONTINGENT PARTIALLY UPON THE CULTURE AND HISTORY IN WHICH THEY ARISE.WE PROPOSE A LARGE-SCALE COMPREHENSIVE INITIATIVE TO PERFORM AN INTEGRATED PROJECT FOCUSED ON BOTH APPLIED NATURAL AND SOCIAL SCIENCE RESEARCH THAT ADDRESSES A REAL-WORLD PROBLEM IN RENEWABLE NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION, AS WELL AS EDUCATION FOCUSED ON EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING IN THE FORM OF INTERNSHIPS AND UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH EXPERIENCES. THE SPECIFIC OBJECTIVES OF OUR PROPOSAL ARE TO 1) ADDRESS INFORMATION DEFICIENCIES IN THE AREA OF HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT BY CONDUCTING RESEARCH IN BOTSWANA AIMED AT IDENTIFYING WAYS FOR PEOPLE IN THE KALAHARI TO BENEFIT FROM THEIR CLOSE PROXIMITY TO WILD CARNIVORES AND TO GAIN SUPPORT FOR EFFORTS TO SAFEGUARD THEIR CATTLE WHILE ALSO TRACKING, MONITORING, AND STEWARDING WILD CARNIVORES; 2) PROVIDE EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO STUDENT PARTICIPANTS THAT INVOLVE REDUCING HUMAN-WILDLIFE CONFLICT IN BOTH BOTSWANA AND THE UNITED STATES, IN THE FORM OF APPLIED UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH PROJECTS IN BOTSWANA AND PROFESSIONAL UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE INTERNSHIPS IN THE UNITED STATES; AND 3) INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF TARLETON STATE UNIVERSITY TO CONDUCT EDUCATION AND RESEARCH ACTIVITIES RELATED TO AGRICULTURE AND NATURAL RESOURCES BY PROMOTING THE PROFESSIONAL GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT OF FACULTY, PROVIDING GRADUATE ASSISTANTSHIPS, AND BUILDING LINKAGES BETWEEN TSU AND PARTICIPATING INSTITUTIONS AND ORGANIZATIONS.

THE OVERALL GOAL OF SAFE IS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND ECONOMIC VIABILITY OF RURAL COMMUNITIES BY DEVELOPING A SUSTAINABLE FOOD SYSTEM MODEL. THE OBJECTIVES ARE: 1) UTILIZE SOIL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES TO IMPROVE CROP AND PASTURE PRODUCTION FOR ENHANCED PRODUCTIVITY AND FOOD QUALITY ACROSS DIFFERENT FOOD SYSTEMS; AND 2) ESTABLISH A FOOD SYSTEM TRAINING CENTER TO PROVIDE SUPPORT IN THE AREAS PRODUCTION, PROCESSING, PRESERVATION, SAFETY, AND FOOD SCIENCE EDUCATION. RESEARCHERS WILL UTILIZE A DAIRY FOOD SYSTEM AND VEGETABLE FOOD SYSTEM TO INVESTIGATE THE IMPACT OF SOIL MANAGEMENT PRACTICES ON CROP, ANIMAL AND FOOD PRODUCTION AND ECONOMICS AND EDUCATION.
