UW-PLATTEVILLE: SUSTAINABLE INTENSIFICATION OF AGRO-ECOSYSTEMS

THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THIS STUDY IS TO PROVIDE FARMERS AND STAKEHOLDERS WITH INFORMATION TO PROMOTE NATIVE POLLINATOR MANAGEMENT IN ORDER TO BOOST SOYBEAN YIELDS WITHOUT REQUIRING EXPANSION OF CURRENT CROPLAND OR FURTHER ENVIRONMENTAL DEGRADATION. THIS PROPOSED PROJECT AIMS TO: (1) DETERMINE WHICH NATIVE BEE SPECIES ARE LOCATED WITHIN/ADJACENT TO AND ARE POLLINATING ARKANSAS SOYBEAN FIELDS, (2) DETERMINE IF THE MOST ABUNDANT NATIVE BEE SPECIES PRESENT CAN INCREASE SOYBEAN YIELDS, (3) DEVELOP REPEATABLE AND STANDARDIZED GROUND-NESTING BEE LARVAE COLLECTION AND REARING TECHNIQUES, AND (4) EVALUATE HOW DIFFERENT PARAMETERS (E.G. LAND USE, GEOGRAPHY, FIELD SIZES, FIELD SHAPE, ETC.) AFFECT NATIVE BEE DIVERSITY, ABUNDANCE, AND COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AROUND AND WITHIN SOYBEAN FIELDS.?
ISOLATED MICROSPORE CULTURE OF SOYBEAN: A PATHWAY TO DOUBLED HAPLOIDS

THIS PROJECT AIMS AT ESTABLISHING A VIBRANT SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION PROGRAM AT SAN HOUSTON STATE UNIVERSITY (SHSU) AND MIDDLE TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY (MTSU) THROUGH ENHANCEMENT OF RESEARCH CAPABILITIES AS WELL AS THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY (TAMU), A LAND GRANT INSTITUTE. SINCE SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE IS A VAST RESEARCH AREA, WE HAVE CHOSEN REGIONALLY IMPORTANT TOPICS (COVER CROPPING, CONSERVATION TILLAGE, AND DIVERSIFIED FORAGE PRODUCTION SYSTEMS) THAT CONTINUE TO RECEIVE SIGNIFICANT ATTENTION FROM LOCAL PRODUCERS, RESEARCHERS, SCIENTIFIC ORGANIZATIONS, MEDIA, AND POLICY MAKES TO IMPROVE SOIL QUALITY AND HEALTH ALONG WITH PROFITABLE CROP AND ANIMAL PRODUCTION. THROUGH THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS LCI PROJECT, WE WILL: 1) EXPAND THE CAPACITY FOR SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE RESEARCH AND EDUCATION AT THE TWO PARTICIPATING NON-LAND GRANT INSTITUTES, 2) PARTNER WITH A LAND GRANT INSTITUTE FOR TRAINING OUR STUDENTS ON THE USE OF LATEST ANALYTICALAND INSTRUMENTATION TECHNIQUES, 3) BETTER EDUCATE BOTH UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE AGRICULTURAL STUDENTS TO LEARN SUSTAINABLE AGROECOSYSTEM PRACTICES AND ITS IMPLEMENTATION, 4) PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS TO INTERACT WITH LOCAL PRODUCERS AND SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITIES, AND 5) IMPROVE SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE CURRICULUM IN ALL THREE PARTICIPATING INSTITUTIONS. OUR APPROACH COMBINES NOVEL TEACHING METHODS WITH FIELD EXPERIMENTS, ANALYTICAL METHODS, CROP AND ECONOMIC MODELING, AND LIFE CYCLE ANALYSES TO ESTIMATE KEY INDICATORS OF BOTH SUSTAINABILITY AND PROFITABILITY. WE WILL TRAIN BOTH UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE USE OF THESE NEW TOOLS AND TECHNIQUES. IN ADDITION, IT IS OUR INTENT TO TRAIN THE STUDENTS AS EFFECTIVE EDUCATORS AND COMMUNICATORS TO CONTRIBUTE TO THE SUITABLE AGRICULTURE WORKFORCE IN THE U.S.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY IN THE DEPARTMENT OF ANIMAL AND VETERINARY SCIENCES, DON B. HUNTLEY COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, NEEDED TO PREPARE STUDENTS FOR GRADUATE SCHOOL, AND CONSEQUENT CAREERS IN ANIMAL NUTRITION/NUTRITIONAL BIOCHEMISTRY OR RELATED FIELDS. THE DEPARTMENT AND COLLEGE ACCORD HIGH PRIORITY TO THE PROPOSED PROJECT BECAUSE OF ITS POTENTIAL TO INCREASE THE NUMBER OF UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS PURSUING GRADUATE-LEVEL EDUCATION, AND MID-LEVEL MANAGEMENT POSITIONS IN THE U. S. DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA) AND RELATED AGENCIES. THE NUMBER OF BACCALAUREATE DEGREE-HOLDERS JOINING GRADUATE SCHOOL AND MID-LEVEL MANAGEMENT POSITIONS IN USDA AND RELATED AGENCIES CONTINUES TO SHRINK WITH UNDERREPRESENTED GRADUATES SHOWING THE MOST DECLINE (U.S. CENSUS BUREAU, 2012). CAL POLY POMONA (CPP) PRIDES ITSELF AND IS PROVIDING QUALITY TEACHING PREMISED ON THE LEARN-BY-DOING MODEL, RESEARCH AND OUTREACH SERVICES TO CLIENTELE. NINE UNDERGRADUATE AND THREE GRADUATE STUDENTS WILL DIRECTLY BENEFIT FROM SUMMER RESEARCH EXPERIENCES THROUGH THREE EXPERIMENTS TO BE CONDUCTED ON CPP'S SPADRA FARM. FURTHERMORE, THE PLACEMENT OF CPP GRADUATES IN COMPETITIVE GRADUATE PROGRAMS WILL POSITIVELY IMPACT RECRUITMENT. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE: (I) ENHANCE RESEARCH EXPERIENCES OF TWELVE UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS AT UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE LEVEL; (II) RESEARCH ALTERNATIVE FORAGE PLANTS FOR THEIR NUTRITIONAL AND MEDICINAL PROPERTIES BENEFICIAL TO SHEEP/GOATS; AND (III) RESEARCH THE BENEFITS OF INTER-SEEDING WINTER/SUMMER ANNUALS WITH LEGUMES ON ANIMAL PERFORMANCE. THIS PROPOSAL WILL ADDRESS THE GOAL OF USDA NIFA-NLGCA FOR THE FISCAL YEAR 2018: FOCUS ON DEVELOPING THE NEXT GENERATION OF RESEARCH, EDUCATION, AND EXTENSION PROFESSIONALS IN THE FOOD AND AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. ?

THIS PROJECT IS TO INITIATE AN INTEGRATED LEARNING AND RESEARCH-BASED PROGRAM WITH THE GOAL TO PROMOTE BOTH UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS' INTERESTS IN FOOD SAFETY AT FLORIDA STATE UNIVERSITY (FSU). THE OVERALL RESEARCH GOAL IS TO DEVELOP TWO ASSAYS USING TWO HIGHLY SELECTIVE AGENTS (ANTIBODY AND APTAMER) FOR THE DETECTION OF THE MAJOR FISH ALLERGEN (I.E., PARVALBUMIN). FOUR SUPPORTING RESEARCH OBJECTIVES ARE (1) PARVALBUMIN PURIFICATION AND CHARACTERIZATION; (2) PARVALBUMIN-SPECIFIC DNA APTAMER DEVELOPMENT AND CHARACTERIZATION; DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION OF (3) AN INDIRECT COMPETITIVE ENZYME-LINKED IMMUNOSORBENT ASSAY (ICELISA) AND (4) AN APTAMER-ANTIBODY BASED SANDWICH ASSAY FOR THE DETECTION OF FISH PARVALBUMIN IN FOODS. THE OVERALL EDUCATIONAL GOAL IS TO PROVIDE UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS WITH MULTIDISCIPLINARY RESEARCH EXPERIENCE IN PROTEIN CHEMISTRY, IMMUNOCHEMISTRY, BIOTECHNOLOGY, AND NANOTECHNOLOGY. IT WILL RECRUIT UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, ESPECIALLY FROM UNDERREPRESENTED GROUPS TO ENCOURAGE THEIR PURSUIT IN FOOD SAFETY. THREE SUPPORTING EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVES ARE (1) ENHANCE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS' INVOLVEMENT AND INTEREST IN THE PROPOSED RESEARCH AND INTERNSHIP PROGRAMS; (2) IMPROVE THE GRADUATE TRAINING AND EDUCATION IN FOOD SAFETY; AND (3) INITIATE THE PROPOSED PROJECT AS A FAITHFUL LEARNING OPPORTUNITY FOR UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS TO PURSUE THEIR FURTHER STUDY OR FOOD SAFETY RELATED JOBS. THE EXPECTED MAJOR OUTCOMES ARE (1) TWO ASSAYS (ICELISA AND APTAMER-ANTIBODY BASED SANDWICH ASSAY) WILL BE DEVELOPED TO DETECT FISH PARVALBUMIN IN FOODS; (2) THE CAPACITY OF FSU TO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND RESEARCH TRAINING OF UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS IN FOOD SCIENCE WILL BE EXPANDED; AND (3) ONE NATIONAL PRIORITY CONCERN, FOOD SAFETY, WILL BE ADDRESSED.

FUELED BY INNOVATION IN FOOD, AGRICULTURE, NATURAL RESOURCES, HUMAN AND SOCIAL SCIENCES, THIS PROJECT LEVERAGES SIUE'S RESOURCES AND FACULTY EXPERTISE FOR ECONOMIC AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT, IMPROVED JOB CREATION AND RETENTION, AND WORKFORCE EDUCATION. AS A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT WITH THE MONROE COUNTY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION AND THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS EXTENSION OFFICE, THE PROJECT SEAMLESSLY BLENDS EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, EXTENSION, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT, (E3) AND WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES IN AN INTEGRATED PROJECT THAT ADDRESSES GOALS OF REGIONAL AND NATIONAL SCOPE.E3 UTILIZES THE SUCCESSFUL COMMUNITIES FRAMEWORK, AN EVIDENCE-BASED MODEL TO CONNECT BUSINESS AND COMMUNITY NEEDS TO TEAMS OF FACULTY AND STUDENTS WITH THE RESOURCES AND EXPERTISE TO SOLVE THEM. BY TACKLING REAL-WORLD OPPORTUNITIES AND CHALLENGES IN AN EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING FORMAT, STUDENTS WILL DEVELOP CRITICAL TECHNICAL AND LEADERSHIP SKILLS, AS WELL AS ENGAGE IN TEAMWORK AND PROBLEM-SOLVING ACTIVITIES. THROUGH DEEP MENTORSHIP FROM FACULTY AND APPLICATION OF THEORY TO PRACTICE, STUDENTS WILL GAIN REAL-WORLD LEADERSHIP EXPERIENCE IN SOLVING PROBLEMS AND DEVELOPING IDEAS TO SUPPORT AGRICULTURE-BASED ECONOMIC GROWTH AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT. BUSINESSES GET THE SCIENCE AND SKILLS THEY NEED TO GROW, WHILE STUDENTS GAIN UNPARALLELED EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND LEADERSHIP EXPERIENCE, INCLUDING STRONG INCORPORATION OF SOCIAL SCIENCE KNOWLEDGE AND THEORY. THE PROJECT ALSO EMPHASIZES WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT THROUGH PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS AND TRAINING FOR INCUMBENT AND FUTURE WORKERS. DUE TO ITS EMPHASIS ON SCIENCE, EDUCATION AND SCIENCE LITERACY, AND RURAL PROSPERITY, THIS PROPOSAL ADDRESSES NLGCA PRIORITIES FROM THE USDA STRATEGIC PLAN (GOAL 1) REE ACTION PLAN (GOAL 6) , AND NIFA STRATEGIC PLAN (GOAL 1).IF FUNDED, THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE SUPPORT FOR:RESEARCH AND EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING PROJECTS IN PARTNERSHIP WITH LOCAL BUSINESSES, FARMERS, AND COMMUNITY GROUPSUNDERGRADUATEAND GRADUATE STUDENT PROJECTS, PRESENTATIONS, AND TRAVELINFRASTRUCTURE/EQUIPMENT: ANALYTICAL INSTRUMENTATION, DRONES, SOFTWARE, UPDATED TECHNOLOGYSTUDENT MEDIA LAB/SCIENCE NEWS WIRE LAUNCHGRADUATE ASSISTANTS WORKING WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF ILLINOIS EXTENSION TO DELIVER AGRICULTURE EDUCATION PROGRAMMING IN REGIONAL MIDDLE AND HIGH SCHOOLSTRAVEL FUNDS FOR FIELD TRIPS, OUTREACH ACTIVITIES, AND OTHER JOINT AGRICULTURE EDUCATION OPPORTUNITIES FOR STUDENTS FROM MIDDLE SCHOOL TO GRADUATE SCHOOL

THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENHANCE THE CAPACITY AND ABILITY TO PREPARE UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS. THIS WILL BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH THE ENHANCEMENT OF THE AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS LABORATORY WITH STATE-OF-THE-ART SAFETY AND PRODUCTION EQUIPMENT. THIS WILL LEAD TO THE DIRECT IMPROVEMENT OF FOUR DIFFERENT AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS COURSES. THIS GRANT WILL SUPPORT THE COORDINATION AND DIRECTION OF THE TAMUK AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS SHOW AND JUDGING AT VARIOUS PROJECT SHOWS AROUND THE STATE. THESE SERVICE LEARNING EVENTS WILL BE DIRECTED BY THE PI AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS, ENHANCING STUDENTS' DEVELOPMENT OF COLLABORATIVE LEADERSHIP AND APPLIED AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS SKILLS. TO ENHANCE THEIR LEADERSHIP SKILLS STUDENTS WILL TAKE PART IN LPI STUDENT AND 360&ORDM; LEADERSHIP ASSESSMENTS THROUGHOUT THE LIFE OF THE PROJECT, TO EVALUATE HOLISTICALLY THEIR LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT. THE AGRICULTURAL MECHANICS FACULTY, WORKING WITH LINCOLN ELECTRIC©, AIRGAS & BRIGGS & STRATTON, WILL ATTEND INDUSTRY PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WORKSHOPS EACH YEAR. THE DIRECT BENEFIT OF THIS FACULTY TRAINING WILL BE SHARED WITH UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS IN THE FOUR AGRICULTURAL MECHANIC COURSES, AND WITH SECONDARY TEACHERS AT PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT EVENTS OFFERED AT TAMUK EACH YEAR. THIS PROJECT SEEKS TO POSITIVELY IMPACT THE ACADEMIC ACHIEVEMENT AND CAREER READINESS OF UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENTS IN AGRICULTURE. ?
MASTERS (MENTORING AGRICULTURE STUDENTS THROUGH TRAINING, EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING, AND RESEARCH SKILLS) FOR THE FUTURE AGRICULTURAL WORKFORCE

THE OVERALL GOAL OF THIS USDA NLGCA PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE ENHANCED EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH OPPORTUNITIES BY WAY OF RESEARCHING MATERNAL RECOGNITION OF PREGNANCY IN MARES. THROUGH THE ACQUISITION OF STATE-OF-THE ART LABORATORY AND CLASSROOM EQUIPMENT, BOTH HIGH SCHOOL AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AND ANIMAL SCIENCE FACULTY WILL BE INVOLVED IN EXPERIMENTAL AND APPLICABLE RESEARCH THAT ADVANCES THE BODY OF KNOWLEDGE IN THE FIELD OF REPRODUCTIVE PHYSIOLOGY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING COURSE-EMBEDDED RESEARCH PROJECTS, COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH EXPERIENCES AT NORTH DAKOTA STATE UNIVERSITY, AND A SUMMER RESEARCH CAMP FOR UPWARD BOUND STUDENTS LED BY UWRF EQUINE MAJORS. UPWARD BOUND SERVES BOTH HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS FROM LOW-INCOME FAMILIES AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS FROM FAMILIES IN WHICH NEITHER PARENT HOLDS A BACHELOR'S DEGREE. THE GOAL OF UPWARD BOUND IS TO INCREASE THE RATE AT WHICH PARTICIPANTS ENROLL IN AND COMPLETE SECONDARY EDUCATION.THE PROPOSED RESEARCH WILL USE THE PLACEMENT OF AN INTERUTERINE DEVICE (IUD) TO INDUCE A PSEUDOPREGNANCY IN MARES AND ENABLE THE RESEARCHERS TO STUDY WHETHER THE EPITHELIAL SODIUM CHANNEL (ENAC) RECEPTOR IS INVOLVED WITH THE MATERNAL RECOGNITION OF PREGNANCY PROCESS. RESULTS ARE ANTICIPATED TO ENHANCE THE UNDERSTANDING AND MANAGEMENT OF REPRODUCTIVE PROCESSES AND FERTILITY ALTERNATIVES WITHIN THE SPECIES. IN ADDITION, BECAUSE BLATANT UNWANTED BEHAVIORS IN MARES ARE CLOSELY LINKED TO HORMONAL CHANGES, THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED WILL PROVIDE THE FOUNDATION FOR DESIGNING A SAFER, MORE EFFECTIVE BEHAVIORAL MANAGEMENT OPTION FOR VETERINARIANS, RESEARCHERS, AND MARE OWNERS.
ENHANCING FOOD SCIENCE CAPACITY THROUGH TRANSFORMATIVE LEARNING EXPERIENCES IN EDUCATION AND RESEARCH

THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THIS GRANT IS TO ASSIST HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS OF THE REGION TO MEET THE HIGHER LEARNING COMMISSION'S (HLC) QUALIFICATION REQUIREMENT FOR DUAL CREDIT TEACHERS BY DEVELOPING TWO EIGHTEEN CREDIT HOUR GRADUATE CERTIFICATE PROGRAMS, ONE IN ANIMAL SCIENCE AND ONE IN PLANT SCIENCE THAT WOULD BE OFFERED IN A HYBRID SETTING (ONLINE AND ON-CAMPUS) OVER A PERIOD OF TWO SUMMERS BY THE AGRICULTURE PROGRAM FACULTY AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL MISSOURI. BEGINNING SEPTEMBER 1, 2017, THE HLC IMPLEMENTED A NEW REQUIREMENT, HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS MUST HAVE EITHER A MASTER'S DEGREE IN THE FIELD THEY ARE TEACHING A DUAL CREDIT, OR IF THE MASTER'S DEGREE IS NOT IN THE FIELD THEY ARE TEACHING IN THEY NEED TO HAVE 18 GRADUATE CREDIT HOURS IN THE FIELD THEY ARE TEACHING DUAL CREDIT. EXISTING DUAL CREDIT TEACHERS WILL HAVE UNTIL 2022 TO BECOME COMPLIANT WITH THIS NEW REQUIREMENT. THIS GRANT WILL SUBSIDIZE (PAY 75%) OF THE COST FOR TEACHERS WHO ARE ACCEPTED IN THE PROGRAM.

TWO OF THE MOST IMPORTANT AGRICULTURE PRODUCTS IN THE MISSOURI OZARK REGION ARE PASTURES AND TREES. WITH OVER HALF OF THIS AREA FORESTED, THE POTENTIAL TO INCREASE AGRICULTURE PRODUCTIVITY LIES IN CREATING SILVOPASTURE SYSTEMS, WHICH COMBINE TREE PRODUCTION AND GRAZING LANDS TO BENEFIT EACH OTHER. THIS PROJECT WILL STUDY THE BEST PRACTICES OF ESTABLISHING SILVOPASTURE SYSTEMS IN MISSOURI. WE WILL MEASURE THE DIFFERENCES IN PLANT ESTABLISHMENT AND GROWTH IN TWO DIFFERENT SYSTEMS: PLANTING TREES DIRECTLY INTO ESTABLISHED GRASSLAND, AND CONVERTING EXISTING TREE STANDS TO INTEGRATE PASTURE BENEATH THEM. WE WILL COMPARE TWO METHODS OF MONITORING TREE AND GRASS GROWTH OVER THREE YEARS WITH TRADITIONAL METHODS (MEASURING PLANT HEIGHT, CUTTING, WEIGHING MATERIAL), AND STATE-OF-THE-ART AERIAL DRONE IMAGING. THE RESULTING TRADITIONAL MEASUREMENTS AND HIGH-RESOLUTION DRONE IMAGES WILL ENABLE US TO BUILD PRECISE MODELS OF TREE AND FORAGE GROWTH AND HEALTH OVER TIME IN THE SILVOPASTURE SYSTEMS. THIS INFORMATION WILL BE VITAL TO ANALYZE SHORT-TERM AND LONG TERM ECONOMICS OF SILVOPASTURE ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT.TWO GRADUATE STUDENTS AND THREE UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT EMPLOYEES WILL BE TRAINED IN FIELD WORK AND RESEARCH METHODS. THE FIELD SITE WILL ALSO BE UTILIZED BY OVER 150 STUDENTS IN THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE AS A LIVING LABORATORY FOR SEVERAL NATURAL RESOURCES COURSES. ADDITIONALLY, OUTREACH EFFORTS IN FIELD DAYS, CONFERENCE PRESENTATIONS, AND RESEARCH PUBLICATIONS WILL EXTEND THIS INFORMATION TO LANDOWNERS, PRODUCERS, PROFESSIONALS, AND RESEARCHERS. THE OVERALL GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE TO (1) ESTABLISH AND PROMOTE NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND METHODS FOR SILVOPASTURE DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS, (2) ENHANCE SILVOPASTURE KNOWLEDGE AND TRAINING, (3) DISSEMINATE KEY FINDINGS FOR BEST PRACTICES FOR SILVOPASTURE ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT, AND (4) TO IMPROVE AND EXPAND THE IMPLEMENTATION AND MANAGEMENT OF SILVOPASTURE IN THE MISSOURI OZARKS.

URBAN LAND AREAS HAVE BEEN EXPANDING GLOBALLY AT A VERY RAPID RATE, EVEN FASTER THAN POPULATION GROWTH. AS THEY EXPAND INTO PREVIOUSLY AGRICULTURAL AREAS, THEY HAVE THE POTENTIAL TO CONSTRAIN FOOD SUPPLY SYSTEMS AND DIMINISH FOOD SECURITY. THIS PUTS INCREASING PRESSURE ON REMAINING AGRICULTURAL LANDS TO PRODUCE THE SAME OR MORE BIOMASS ON LESS LAND FOR A LARGER POPULATION, YET THERE IS LITTLE SCIENTIFIC EVALUATION OF HOW THE GROWTH OF URBAN CENTERS WILL AFFECT REGIONAL AGRICULTURE. LEFT UNADDRESSED, THIS INHERENT TRADE-OFF BETWEEN URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL LAND RESOURCES COULD LEAD TO A DECREASED RESILIENCE IN AND AROUND URBAN AREAS, ESPECIALLY THOSE ALREADY VULNERABLE TO ENVIRONMENTAL RISKS.IN RAPIDLY URBANIZING AREAS SUCH AS PHOENIX AND OTHER SOUTHWESTERN CITIES, THE TRADE-OFFS BETWEEN URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL RESOURCE NEEDS ARE EXACERBATED BY LIMITED RESOURCE AVAILABILITY, ESPECIALLY FOR WATER. THEREFORE, MORE RESEARCH IS NEEDED TO CREATE SYNERGIES BETWEEN URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL RESOURCE DEMANDS, RATHER THAN COMPETITION. SOME PROMISING AREAS OF OPPORTUNITY AT THIS COMPETING RESOURCE-DEMAND NEXUS INCLUDE THE USE OF EXCESS STORMWATER AND TREATED MUNICIPAL WASTEWATER FOR AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION, USE OF BIOSOLIDS FROM URBAN WASTEWATER TREATMENT, COMPOST FROM URBAN FOOD WASTE AS AGRICULTURAL FERTILIZER, AND MANURE FROM AGRICULTURAL OPERATIONS FOR URBAN AGRICULTURE NUTRIENT, WATER, AND SOIL HEALTH NEEDS.GIVEN THAT AGRICULTURE IS A VITAL PART OF THE SOUTHWEST'S ECONOMY, AND ENCROACHMENT OF AGRICULTURE BY URBAN EXPANSION, IN ADDITION TO CONCERNS OF DECREASING WATER SUPPLY, HAS THE POTENTIAL TO SEVERELY IMPACT LIVELIHOODS AND FOOD SECURITY IN THE REGION,THEOVERALL GOAL OF THIS GRANT WILL BE TO IMPROVE ARIZONA STATE UNIVERSITY'S (ASUS) CAPACITY TO PERFORM AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION TO ADDRESS CHALLENGES AND IDENTIFY EMERGING OPPORTUNITIES AT THE URBAN-AGRICULTURE NEXUS IN THE DESERT SOUTHWEST.THE GOALS AND ACTIVITIES OF THIS PROJECT DIRECTLY ADDRESS GOAL 6 OF THE USDA'S RESEARCH, EDUCATION AND ECONOMICS ACTION PLAN BY HELPING TORECRUIT, CULTIVATE, AND DEVELOP THE NEXT GENERATION OF SCIENTISTS, ENGINEERS, AND LEADERSIN AGRICULTURE THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE NEW UNDERGRADUATE COURSE AND THE MULTIPLE OPPORTUNITIES PROVIDED TO STUDENTS TO GAIN LEADERSHIP AND MENTORING EXPERIENCE. THIS PROJECT IS ALSO IN LINE WITH USDA'S STRATEGIC PLAN, GOAL 1, THAT AIMS TOASSIST RURAL COMMUNITIES TO CREATE PROSPERITY, THROUGH OUTREACH AND EDUCATION EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT SUPPORTS MULTIPLE SUBGOALS OF GOAL 1 OF THE NIFA STRATEGIC PLAN AS OUR GOAL TO CONNECT URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL STAKEHOLDERS WILL ULTIMATELY HELPADVANCE FOOD SECURITYIN THE REGION (SUBGOAL 1.1.) AND OUR EDUCATIONAL OBJECTIVES WILLSUPPORT A DIVERSE WORKFORCE IN SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURE(SUBGOAL 1.6). FURTHERMORE, OUR RESEARCH OBJECTIVES DIRECTLY SUPPORT SUBGOAL 1.3 THROUGH THE IMPROVEDEVALUATION OF RECLAIMED RESOURCES IN ARID ENVIRONMENT AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION.WE WILL ACHIEVE OUR PROJECTGOALS AND OBJECTIVES BY EXPANDING ASU'S CAPABILITY TO PERFORM AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH AND EDUCATION, AND BY ENGAGING LOCAL URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES AROUND THE TOPIC OF ADDRESSING CHALLENGES AND IDENTIFYING EMERGING OPPORTUNITIES AT THE URBAN-AGRICULTURE NEXUS IN THE DESERT SOUTHWEST. TO ENHANCE ASU'S AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION CAPACITY, WE WILL DEVELOP AN UNDERGRADUATE-LEVEL EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING COURSE JOINTLY WITH MESA COMMUNITY COLLEGE. THIS COURSE WILL CONSIST OF HANDS-ON RESEARCH PROJECTS RELATED TO URBAN-AGRICULTURE NEXUS, INCLUDING FIELD, LAB, AND DATA ANALYSIS TRAINING FOR THE STUDENTS. TO INCREASE ASU'S ABILITY TO PERFORM AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH, WE ARE PARTNERING WITH THE USDA ARID LANDS AGRICULTURAL RESEARCH CENTER TO MENTOR TWO MASTERS LEVEL PROJECTS FOCUSED ON UNDERSTANDING RISKS AND BENEFITS OF USING URBAN RESOURCES (BIOSOLIDS, WASTEWATER, COMPOSTS, ETC.) IN ARID LAND AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION. TO ENGAGE THE URBAN AND AGRICULTURAL COMMUNITIES, WE WILL HOST KICK-OFF AND SUMMATIVE WORKSHOPS, CREATE A STUDENT-LED WEBINAR SERIES, AND CREATE A STAKEHOLDER ADVISORY GROUP TO INFORM AND ASSESS PROJECT ACTIVITIES. IF THE GOALS OF THE PROJECT ARE MET, WE HOPE TO CREATE A LONG-TERM CULTURE OF AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION AND RESEARCH INTEREST AT ASU AS WELL AS TO FOSTER NEW CONNECTIONS AND COLLABORATIONS TO CREATE SYNERGISTIC OPPORTUNITIES AT THE URBAN-AGRICULTURE NEXUS.

THE PROJECT 'BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN STAKEHOLDERS INVOLVED IN THE LOCAL PRODUCTION, MARKETING AND EDUCATION OF VEGETABLE PRODUCTION IN WESTERN MISSOURI' IS A COLLABORATIVE EFFORT OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL MISSOURI, POWELL GARDENS, AGRIMISSOURI, WARRENSBURG MAIN STREET, AND SEDALIA AREA FARMERS' MARKET INC., THAT WILL GREATLY INCREASE THE CAPACITY AND DIVERSITY OF LOCAL VEGETABLE PRODUCTION IN WESTERN MISSOURI BY BUILDING PARTNERSHIPS BETWEEN THESE ORGANIZATIONS. THESE PARTNERSHIPS WILL BE STRENGTHENED BY PROVIDING INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITIES TO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS AT POWELL GARDENS, AGRIMISSOURI AND THE WARRENSBURG AND SEDALIA FARMERS MARKETS, BY CONDUCTING VARIETY TRIALS AT POWELL GARDENS AND UNIVERSITY OF CENTRAL MISSOURI USING BOTH OPEN FIELD AND HIGH TUNNEL TECHNOLOGY, BY CONDUCTING MARKETING SURVEYS AND DEVELOPMENT OF NEW MARKETING STRATEGIES TO CONSUMERS AND PRODUCERS, BY PROVIDING MINI-GRANTS FOR UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE STUDENTS AND THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW UNDERGRADUATE COLLEGE COURSES, PLUS WORKSHOP OFFERING TO VENDORS, PRODUCERS AND CONSUMERS ABOUT VARIOUS PRODUCTION TECHNOLOGIES AND NEW VARIETIES SUITABLE FOR WESTERN MISSOURI. ADDITIONALLY, THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN CONNECTIONS BETWEEN UCM AND HIGH SCHOOL TO INCREASE RECRUITMENT OF NOT ONLY RURAL HIGH STUDENTS BUT ALSO MINORITY AND URBAN STUDENTS BY DRAWING MORE ATTENTION TO VEGETABLE PRODUCTION AND DISTRIBUTION THROUGH FARMERS MARKETS, AS WELL AS THE BENEFITS OF EARNING AN UNDERGRADUATE DEGREE IN AGRICULTURE.

MECHANISM OF RECOMBINANT PROTEIN ACCUMULATION IN MAIZE SEED

IN THIS PROPOSAL, WE SEEK TO LEVERAGE THE LOCAL FARMING MOVEMENT TO DRAW A MORE URBAN AND DIVERSE POPULATION INTO AGRICULTURAL AND FOOD SCIENCES. WE ALSO SEEK TO SUPPORT THE LOCAL FARMING MOVEMENT BY DEVELOPING A MODERN AND COST-EFFECTIVE SMALL-SCALE HARVESTING MACHINE. THIS IS A MULTI-DISCIPLINARY PROJECT BRINGING TOGETHER FACULTY AND UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT RESEARCHERS FROM AGRICULTURAL ENGINEERING AND AGRICULTURAL ECONOMICS. THIS PROJECT INTEGRATES THE MACHINE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT WITH AN OUTREACH SUMMER CAMP FOR HIGH-SCHOOL STUDENTS, THEREBY PROVIDING LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT FOR THE STUDENT RESEARCHERS AND A RECRUITING PATHWAY FOR THE COLLEGE OF AGRICULTURE, FOOD, AND ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCES AT UW-RIVER FALLS.

SILVERLEAF WHITEFLY (SLW) AND BROWN MARMORATED STINK BUG (BMSB) ARE INVASIVE INSECTS WHICH CAUSE SEVERE LOSSES IN TOMATO. INSECTICIDAL CONTROL OF THESE PESTS ARE HARMFUL TO THE ENVIRONMENT AND APPLICATORS. ACYLSUGARS ARE A PLANT PRODUCED INSECT RESISTANCE COMPOUND FOUND IN TOMATOES. ACYLSUGAR-MEDIATED INSECT RESISTANCE IN TOMATO COULD PROVIDE SAFE ALTERNATIVE CONTROL. DIFFERENT ACYLSUGAR CHEMISTRIES (CHEMOTYPES) DIFFERENTIALLY AFFECT INSECT SPECIES, SO USING SUITABLE LEVELS OF THE MOST EFFECTIVE CHEMOTYPES IS CRITICAL FOR ACYLSUGAR-MEDIATED RESISTANCE OF MULTIPLE PESTS. THE CORNELL UNIVERSITY (CU) TOMATO BREEDING PROGRAM CREATED TOMATO LINES PRODUCING HIGH LEVELS OF ACYLSUGAR WITH DIFFERENT CHEMOTYPES, PROVIDING A PLATFORM FOR TRIALING THE SLW/BMSB CONTROL ACROSS ACYLSUGAR CHEMOTYPES AND TO FACILITATE CREATION OF INSECT RESISTANT TOMATO LINES.OUR OVERALL GOAL FOR THIS INTERACTIVE RESEARCH PROJECT BETWEEN TENNESSEE TECHNOLOGICAL UNIVERSITY (TTU) AND CU IS THE IDENTIFICATION OF TOMATO LINES WITH OPTIMAL ACYLSUGAR-MEDIATED SLW/BMSB CONTROL. OUR RESEARCH WILL BREED ACYLSUGAR PRODUCTION INTO HORTICULTURALLY ACCEPTABLE LINES THAT CAN BE USED BY SEED COMPANIES AND PRODUCERS FOR SUSTAINABLE AND ENVIRONMENTALLY FRIENDLY TOMATO PRODUCTION. WE WILL ALSO LOOK AT HOW CHANGES IN THE ACYLSUGAR CHEMISTRIES DIFFERENTIALLY AFFECT FEEDING AND DAMAGE FROM SLW AND BMSB. IN DOING THIS RESEARCH WE WILL HAVE SEVERAL CAPACITY-BUILDING OUTCOMES TO BE ACHIEVED AT TTU INCLUDING 1) CREATING A TTU/CU RESEARCH PARTNERSHIP 2) DEVELOPING A GRADUATE RESEARCH ASSISTANTSHIP FOR AN UNDERREPRESENTED STUDENT AT TTU, 3) PROVIDING SUMMER RESEARCH INTERNSHIPS FOR UNDERREPRESENTED UNDERGRADUATES AT TTU 4) PURCHASE EQUIPMENT AT TTU TO SUPPORT ENTOMOLOGICAL/HORTICULTURAL RESEARCH
CAPACITY BUILDING FOR SOIL-PLANT-ANIMAL INTERACTION RESEARCH AND EDUCATION

COMMODITY PRICES FLUCTUATE CONTINUOUSLY THROUGHOUT THE YEAR DUE TO CHANGES IN THE UNDERLYING SUPPLY AND DEMAND VARIABLES. UNDERSTANDING COMMODITY PRICE BEHAVIOR HELPS FARMERS IN MANAGING THEIR PRODUCTION RISKS AND MAKING PROPER MARKETING DECISIONS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD THE CAPACITY FOR DELIVERING AGRICULTURAL MARKETING COURSES BY ESTABLISHING A STATE OF THE ART MARKETING LAB IN THE HUTSON SCHOOL OF AGRICULTURE AT MURRAY STATE UNIVERSITY. THE PLANNED LAB WILL INCORPORATE LATEST COMPUTER HARDWARE, TRADING, AND SIMULATION SOFTWARE, ACCESS TO MARKET INFORMATION, AND DATA RESOURCES MADE AVAILABLE TO STUDENTS TO PROVIDE TRUE "HANDS-ON" EDUCATION IN ORDER TO ENHANCE THEIR UNDERSTANDING OF THE ROLE OF COMMODITY MARKETS IN TODAY'S AGRICULTURE. STUDENTS BETTER UNDERSTAND THE ROLE OF VARIOUS STAKEHOLDERS IN THE COMMODITY MARKETS AREA SUCH AS PROCESSORS, HEDGERS, AND SPECULATORS. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, AGRIBUSINESS STUDENTS GAIN VALUABLE SKILLS REGARDING VARIOUS FUNDAMENTAL AND TECHNICAL PRICE FORECASTING METHODS, FAMILIARITY WITH THE BROKERAGE OPERATIONS AND COMMODITY PRICE RISK MANAGEMENT. BESIDES ESTABLISHING A MARKETING LAB, THE PRESENT PROPOSAL ALSO AIMS TO PROVIDE SHORT-TERM RESEARCH PROJECT OPPORTUNITIES TO UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS LEADING TO PRESENTATIONS. ULTIMATELY, THIS PROJECT RESULTS IN READILY EMPLOYABLE AGRIBUSINESS GRADUATES MEETING INDUSTRY NEED IN THE AREA OF COMMODITY MARKETING.
BUILDING CAPACITY AND MEETING THE DEMAND: INCREASING TEACHER CERTIFICATION AVENUES IN AGRICULTURAL EDUCATION

TITLE: PARTNERS AGAINST INVASIVE SPECIES (PAIS)PROJECT DIRECTOR - MCCALL, JOHN THE UNIVERSITY OF WEST ALABAMACO-PROJECT DIRECTOR- STANTON, LEE THE UNIVERSITY OF WEST ALABAMATHE UNIVERSITY OF WEST ALABAMA AND THE SUMTER COUNTY SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT ARE COLLABORATING IN A JOINT GRANT EFFORT TO EDUCATE AND PROVIDE PROVIDE OUTREACH AND MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES TO REGIONAL LANDOWNERS, FORESTERS, FARMERS, RANCHERS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS REGARDING INVASIVE SPECIES IN WEST ALABAMA AND EAST MISSISSIPPI. THIS REGION HAS NUMEROUS EXOTIC INVASIVE SPECIES SUCH AS RED IMPORTED FIRE ANTS, KUDZU, AND OTHERS WHICH HAVE LONG TROUBLED THE REGION. HOWEVER, TWO LESS WELL-PUBLICIZED SPECIES ARE CURRENTLY OF GREAT CONCERN. AN INVASIVE GRASS, COGONGRASS (IMPERATA CYLINDRICA), IS NOW FOUND IN MORE THAN 75% OF ALABAMA COUNTIES. IT IMPACTS CROPS, RANGELANDS, AND TIMBER, PRIMARILY THROUGH COMPETITIVE INTERACTIONS. THE ABRASIVE NATURE OF COGONGRASS MAKES IT RELATIVELY INEDIBLE, CONTRIBUTING TO ITS ABILITY TO OUTCOMPETE NATIVE GRASS SPECIES. SIMILARLY, FERAL SWINE (SUS SCROFA), WITH AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF AT LEAST 64 MILLION NATIONALLY, HAVE HAD TREMENDOUS IMPACTS ON A VARIETY OF CROPS, AS WELL AS BEING A CARRIER FOR A VARIETY OF HUMAN AND LIVESTOCK DISEASES. IN THE UNITED STATES, ANNUAL EXPENSES RELATED TO CROP DAMAGE AND ANIMAL CONTROL RELATED TO FERAL SWINE EXCEED $1.5 BILLION. THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO: ENSURE STAKEHOLDER AWARENESS AND DEVELOP PROGRAMS TO ENHANCE KNOWLEDGE OF THE DAMAGE WHICH INVASIVE SPECIES INFLICT ON THE REGION; PROVIDE OUTREACH ASSISTANCE TO REGIONAL LANDOWNERS IN THE CONTROL AND MANAGEMENT OF THE INVASIVE SPECIES; ENHANCE CAREER OPPORTUNITIES FOR UNDERSERVED STEM STUDENTS; AND DEVELOP A REGIONAL CENTER OF EXPERTISE AND DEDICATION TOWARD RESEARCH AND MANAGEMENT OF INVASIVE SPECIES.

THE UNIVERSITY OF WISCONSIN - RIVER FALLS DEPARTMENT OF ANIMAL AND FOOD SCIENCE IS ANUALLY ENROLLING NEARLY FOUR HUNDRED UNDERGRADUATE STUDENTS WITH A STATED CAREER INTEREST IN THE AREA OF COMPANION ANIMAL SCIENCE. THIS INTERGRATED PROPOSAL SPECIFICALLY ADDRESSES NEEDS CREATED BY ENROLLMENT PRESSURES OF THE PROGRAM TO GENERATE INNOVATIVE EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITY FOR THE STUDENTS. THROUGH UNIQUE COLLABORATION WITH TWO NON-PROFIT AGENCIES, STUDENTS WILL GAIN BOTH STRENGTHENED CLASSROOM LEARNING EXPERIENCES, AS WELL AS OPPORTUNITIES FOR FIELD-BASED INTERNSHIPS.SUPPORTING OBJECTIVES ARE FOURFOLD: (1) DEVELOPMENT OF TWO NOVEL COMPANION ANIMAL SCIENCE UNDERGRADUATE COURSES, (2) EXPANSION OF THE UNIVERSITY'S NOVEL SERVICE DOG TRAINING INTERNSHIP TO INCLUDE AN AMBASSADOR PROGRAM WITH THE AIM OF HONING STUDENT LEADERSHIP SKILLS THROUGH PUBLIC EDUCATION AND OUTREACH, (3) CREATION OF A INTERCOLLEGIATE NETWORK OF NORTH AMERICAN COLLEGES WITH UNDERGRADUATE SERVICE DOG TRAINING PROGRAMS, CULMINATING IN A SUMMIT FOR IDEA-EXCHANGE AND STUDENT COLLABORATION, AND (4) FIELD-BASED INTERNSHIP DEVELOPMENT TO ENGAGE STUDENTS DIRECTLY WITH UNDERSERVED SECTORS OF THE PET-OWNING POPULATION THROUGH A NATIONALLY UNIQUE NON-PROFIT VETERINARY HOPSITAL. THE PROPOSED HIGH-IMPACT ACTIVITIES WILL SERVE AS MODELS FOR OTHER UNGRADUATE ANIMAL SCIENCE PROGRAMS EXPANDING INTO COMPANION ANIMAL SCIENCE DISCIPLINES. ENHANCEMENT OF THE COMPANION ANIMAL PROGRAM IS ESPECIALLY POISED TO ATTRACT, RECRUIT AND RETAIN STUDENTS WHO LACKED OPPORTUNITY OR ACCESS TO TRADITIONAL "GATEWAY" AGRICULTURE EXPERIENCES IN THE K-12 PERIOD, SUCH AS AGRICULTURE EDUCATION CURRICULUM, FFA AND 4H. STUDENTS WILL EMERGE FROM THE ENHANCED PROGRAM PREPARED TO LEAD, COMMUNICATE AND WORK COLLABORATIVELY TO CREATE A DIVERSE AGRICULTURE WORKFORCE THAT IS REPRESENTATIVE OF THE NATIONAL WORKFORCE.

FARMERS OFTEN DIRECTLY MARKET THEIR PRODUCTS TO CONSUMERS. THIS INTERACTION IS UNIQUE TO MANY MARKETED FOOD PRODUCTS AND OPENS UP MARKETING STRATEGIES NOT AVAILABLE TO OTHER ENTITIES. CONSUMERS MAY GAIN PRESTIGE OR SOCIAL STATUS BY PURCHASING FOODS IN THIS MANNER AND SUGGESTS FURTHER MARKET SEGMENTATION WHICH HAS THE POTENTIAL TO BENEFIT FARMERS. IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THESE UNDERSERVED MARKET SEGMENTATIONS MAY IMPROVE FARMER PROFITABILITY WHILE IMPROVING THE VALUE DELIVERED TO CONSUMERS. IDENTIFICATION OF EXISTING MARKETING STRATEGIES OF FARMERS WILL AID THE PROJECT TEAM AS THEY SEEK TO IDENTIFY STRATEGIES APPEALING TO CONSUMERS SEEKING PRESTIGE OR SOCIAL STATUS FROM THEIR FOOD PURCHASES. BEHAVIORS OF CONSUMERS SEEKING PRESTIGE OR SOCIAL STATUS FROM FOOD PURCHASES THAT INCLUDE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY LEVELS AND NEUROPHYSIOLOGICAL RESPONSES WILL BE DETERMINED IN AN EXPERIMENTAL AUCTION OF FOOD FROM FARMERS. FOLLOWING COMPLETION OF THE EXPERIMENTAL AUCTIONS, FIELD EXPERIMENTS WILL BE CONDUCTED WITH FARMERS' MARKETS TO SEE HOW PURCHASING PATTERNS CHANGED. ECONOMIC IMPACT OF THE MARKETING STRATEGIES WILL BE DETERMINED. STRATEGIES FOR FARMERS WISHING TO MARKET TO PRESTIGE-SEEKING AND SOCIAL STATUS ACHIEVING CONSUMERS WILL ALSO BE IDENTIFIED. THIS PROJECT ASSISTS SMALL- AND MEDIUM-SIZED FARMERS IN DEVELOPING NEW MARKETING STRATEGIES TO INCREASE EFFICIENCY AND PROFITABILITY IN AN EVER CHANGING CONSUMER LANDSCAPE.
BUILDING RESEARCH AND EDUCATION CAPACITIES TO STRENGTHEN THE BLACK WALNUT BREEDING PROGRAM
AN INTEGRATED PROJECT TO PROMOTE STUDENT INTEREST AND SUCCESS IN AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES THROUGH AN APPLIED MICROBIOLOGICAL PERSPECTIVE.

THIS PROPOSAL SEEKS FUNDING TO ESTABLISH OL&EACUTE;! LUBBOCK, IN ASSOCIATION WITH A STATE-WIDE INITIATIVE TO COMBAT OBESITY THROUGH THE DESIGN AND PROGRAMMING OF NATURALIZED, OUTDOOR LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS (OLE). IT WILL BE A MULTIDISCIPLINARY COLLABORATIVE BETWEEN FACULTY FROM LANDSCAPE ARCHITECTURE (LA) HUMAN DEVELOPMENT AND FAMILY STUDIES (HDFS) AND INTERIOR DESIGN (ID). THE COLLABORATIVE WILL BE ONE OF SEVERAL REGIONAL EFFORTS SPONSORED BY OL&EACUTE;! TEXAS, A PROGRAM DEVELOPED BY THE DEPARTMENT OF STATE HEALTH SERVICE (DSHS), OBESITY PREVENTION PROGRAM, TO PROVIDE DESIGN AND PROGRAMING ASSISTANCE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF OUTDOOR LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS THROUGHOUT TEXAS. THE PROGRAM IS BASED ON THE PREVENTING OBESITY BY DESIGN (POD) MODEL PROGRAM DEVELOPED BY THE NATURAL LEARNING INITIATIVE (NLI). THEIR EVIDENCE-BASED, BEST PRACTICE INDICATORS PROMOTE THE DESIGN OF CHILDCARE CENTER OUTDOOR LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS THAT INCREASE CHILDHOOD PHYSICAL ACTIVITY, INCREASE AGE-APPROPRIATE MOTOR SKILLS, INCREASE FOOD AWARENESS, AND PROMOTE HEALTHIER LIFESTYLES.RESEARCH SHOWS THAT WELL-DESIGNED OUTDOOR LEARNING ENVIRONMENTS (AKA PLAYGROUNDS) AT CHILDCARE CENTERS INCREASE LEVELS OF PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND SIGNIFICANTLY REDUCES SEDENTARY BEHAVIOR. SINCE 20 PERCENT OF CHILDREN NATIONWIDE AGES 2-5 ARE CONSIDERED OBESE, CHILD CARE CENTERS REPRESENT A SIGNIFICANT, EARLY INTERVENTION OPPORTUNITY FOR COMBATING THIS NATIONWIDE OBESITY EPIDEMIC. INTERVENTIONS THAT EMPHASIZE NATURALIZATION AS AN INTERVENTION STRATEGY HAVE SHOWN MANY POSITIVE MENTAL AND PHYSICAL HEALTH EFFECTS AS A RESULT OF THEIR INTERACTION WITH THE NATURAL ENVIRONMENT. ONE OF THE MOST ESSENTIAL ACTIVITIES IS FRUIT AND VEGETABLE GARDENING. ALONG WITH THE CURRICULUM THAT TEACHES CHILDREN ABOUT WHERE THEIR FOOD COMES FROM AND HOW IT IS PRODUCED, ALMOST ALL CENTERS ARE ABLE TO SUPPLEMENT THEIR DAILY MEALS AND SNACKS WITH HEALTHY FOODS GROWN ON SITE IN THEIR OWN GARDENING AREAS.THE TEXAS TECH TEAM HAS WORKED WITH DSHS AND NLI OVER THE PAST EIGHTEEN MONTHS AS MEMBERS OF THE STATE-WIDE LEADERSHIP TEAM, AND TO SPONSOR THE FIRST PILOT DEMONSTRATION DESIGN WORKSHOP IN TEXAS. OF THE REGIONAL PILOT PROJECTS, IT IS THE ONLY ONE SPONSORED BY A UNIVERSITY-BASED TEAM. OL&EACUTE;! LUBBOCK WILL BUILD UPON THEIR WORK WITH DSHS TO COMBINE COMMUNITY OUTREACH, BOTH EMPIRICAL AND APPLIED RESEARCH, AND A PROGRAM OF EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT FOR GRADUATE STUDENTS. THE MODEL USES A TRAIN-THE-TRAINER METHODOLOGY TO TRANSFER KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THE DESIGN, MANAGEMENT AND PROGRAMMING OF OUTDOOR SPACE TO SUPPORT HEALTHY OUTCOMES. THE TEAM WILL ALSO DRAW UPON THE RESOURCES AVAILABLE THROUGH THE TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY'S OBESITY RESEARCH CLUSTER, A MULTIDISCIPLINARY, UNIVERSITY-WIDE TEAM OF RESEARCHERS, ADVISORS AND MENTORS.

THE "GLOBAL AGLEADER: DEVELOPMENT OF LEADERSHIP AND GLOBAL COMPETENCY TO ENHANCE RECRUITMENT AND RETENTION OF MINORITY STUDENTS" PROJECT ADDRESSES THE OBSTACLES REGULARLY FACED IN RECRUITING AND RETAINING THE STUDENTS FROM MINORITY COMMUNITIES IN UNDERGRADUATE AND GRADUATE AGRICULTURAL PROGRAMS. THOUGH THERE ARE PREDICTIONS OF IMPRESSIVE JOB GROWTH IN AGRICULTURE, THERE IS A DOCUMENTED LACK OF SUPPLY OF TRAINED WORKFORCE THAT CAN CATER TO THE REQUIREMENTS OF A RAPIDLY TRANSFORMING AGRICULTURE SECTOR. BUT YOUNG STUDENTS FROM MINORITY COMMUNITIES ARE UNAWARE OF SUCH JOB OPPORTUNITIES, HAVE PERCEIVED ENTRY BARRIERS, AND LACK PROFESSIONAL NETWORKS. WITH MINORITY STUDENTS IN MIND, THE PROJECT WILL DEVELOP A FORWARD-LOOKING AND MULTI-PRONGED APPROACH BY TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THE FONDNESS FOR SOCIAL MEDIA AND TECHNOLOGY AMONG YOUNGER GENERATIONS. IT WILL USE WEB-BASED CONTENTS TO HELP THE STUDENTS IN FORMING PROFESSIONAL SOCIAL NETWORKS AND IN INCREASING THEIR AWARENESS ABOUT THE CAREER OPPORTUNITIES IN AGRICULTURE. THE PROJECT PROPOSES INTERNATIONAL AND DOMESTIC EXPERIENCES AT REPUTABLE ORGANIZATIONS, MENTORING, INTERNSHIPS, AND SUMMER INSTITUTES TO HELP STUDENTS IN CAREER DECISIONS. THE PROJECT WILL IMPROVE THE ABILITY OF THE TEXAS STATE UNIVERSITY'S (TEXAS STATE) TO I) PROVIDE BETTER EDUCATION TO AGRICULTURAL STUDENTS WITH EMPHASIS ON MINORITY STUDENTS, AND II) CATER TO THE NEEDS OF OTHER STAKEHOLDERS SUCH AS FARMERS AND AGRIBUSINESSES. IT WILL ALSO FOSTER TEXAS STATE'S LINKS WITH REPUTABLE INTERNATIONAL AGRICULTURAL INSTITUTIONS. INTENDED RESULTS FROM THE PROJECT INCLUDE: BETTER RECRUITMENT/RETENTION OF MINORITY STUDENTS; AND PREPARING A DYNAMIC BASE OF STUDENTS WITH BOTH TECHNICAL SKILLS AND SOFT-SKILLS REQUIRED TO LEAD IN THEIR CHOSEN CAREER.

THE LOWER MISSISSIPPI RIVER VALLEY (LMRV) INCLUDES MORE THAN 4 MILLION HA OF IRRIGATED CROPLAND IN PORTIONS OF ARKANSAS, KENTUCKY, LOUISIANA, MISSISSIPPI, MISSOURI, AND TENNESSEE AND IS ONE THE MOST PRODUCTIVE AGRICULTURAL REGIONS IN THE UNITED STATES. NATIONALLY, ARKANSAS AND MISSISSIPPI RANK THIRD AND EIGHTH, RESPECTIVELY, IN TERMS OF IRRIGATED ACRES. WHILE OTHER AREAS DECLINED, THE AMOUNT OF IRRIGATED CROPLAND IN THE LMRV HAS BEEN STEADILY INCREASING AND GREW AT AN AVERAGE ANNUAL RATE OF APPROXIMATELY 2% BETWEEN 2002 AND 2012. AS THE CLIMATE BECOMES DRIER IN THE WESTERN U.S., IRRIGATED CROPLANDS SUCH AS THOSE OF THE LMRV WILL GROW MORE IMPORTANT WITH EACH PASSING DECADE.AS AGRICULTURE SEEKS TO MITIGATE THE IMPACTS OF A CHANGING CLIMATE ON WATER AND SOIL RESOURCES AS WELL AS REDUCE ITS OWN ENVIRONMENTAL FOOTPRINT, FURROW-RICE OFFERS POTENTIAL BENEFITS TO PRODUCERS. HOWEVER, THERE ARE ALSO KNOWN CHALLENGES WITH THE SYSTEM. IN PARTICULAR, GRAIN YIELDS HAVE TENDED TO BE LOWER THAN TRADITIONAL FLOOD SYSTEMS. A BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF NITROGEN DYNAMICS AND WEED PRESSURE IN THESE SYSTEMS IS IMPORTANT FOR MANAGMENT OF FURROW IRRIGATED RICE. THE WATER-SAVING POTENTIAL AND OTHER KEY ASPECTS OF THE SYSTEM REMAIN IN QUESTION AND REQUIRE ADDITIONAL RESEARCH TO DETERMINE IF IT HAS BROAD APPLICABILITY TO THE LMRV WHERE THE MAJORITY OF THE NATION'S RICE IS PRODUCED.WINTER COVER CROPS MAY ALSO HELP ADDRESS SOME OF THE CHALLENGES ASSOCIATED WITH THE FURROW-RICE SYSTEM. FOR EXAMPLE, COVER CROPS HAVE BEEN SHOWN TO SUPPRESS WEEDS. PIGWEEDS, IN PARTICULAR, REQUIRE SUNLIGHT TO GERMINATE AND THUS, COVER CROPS MAY HELP SHADE OUT THE PROBLEMATIC PIGWEED AND OTHER WEED SPECIES. MOREOVER, COVER CROP MIXTURES TYPICALLY INCLUDE ONE OR MORE LEGUME SPECIES TO FIX NITROGEN AND THUS, MAY REDUCE N FERTILIZER NEEDED TO COMPENSATE FOR INCREASED NITRIFICATION/DENITRIFICATION LOSSES REPORTED FOR FURROW-IRRIGATION RICE SYSTEMS. REDUCING NITROGEN USE IN AGRICULTURE IS IMPORTANT BECAUSE THE GLOBAL NCYCLE IS HIGHLY PERTURBED. BY ADDRESSING THESE CHALLENGES IN FURROW IRRIGATED RICE PRODUCTION, THE POTENTIAL FOR A SOYBEAN-RICE ROTATION WHERE ANNUAL TILLAGE IS NOT NEEDED TO KNOCK DOWN RICE LEVEES OR BUILD BEDS FOR SOYBEAN PRODUCTION WILL BE ENHANCED PROVIDING GREATER POTENTIAL FOR INPUT REDUCTIONS, GREATER RESILIENCY IN A CLIMATE CHANGING WORLD, AND MAINTAINED/ENHANCED FARM PROFITIABILITY.THIS LARGE-SCALE, INTEGRATED PROJECT AIMS TO FOCUS ON THE AREAS OF RESEARCH AND EDUCATION, WHILE BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF THE COLLEGES OF AGRICULTURE AT ARKANSAS STATE UNIVERSITY, SOUTHEAST MISSOURI STATE UNIVERSITY, AND UNIVERSITY OF TENNESSEE AT MARTIN. THIS COLLABORATIVE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THESE MID-SOUTH INSTITUTIONS' ABILITY TO CONDUCT QUALITY, DYNAMIC RESEARCH AND INNOVATIVE EDUCATION IN THE AGRICULTURAL SCIENCES. BY SOLIDIFYING THIS REGIONAL TEAM, WE ARE BUILDING A LONG-LASTING COLLABORATION TO ADDRESS REGIONAL AGRICULTURAL ISSUES.THIS MULTIDISCIPLINARY, MULTI-INSTITUTIONAL PROJECT WILL TARGET A WIDE RANGING AUDIENCE. FACULTY MEMBERS WILL ENHANCE THEIR RESEARCH AND TEACHING EXPERTISE; HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS WILL RECEIVE CURRICULAR DEVELOPMENT IN AGRICULTURAL SCIENCE; HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS WILL BE EXPOSED TO AGRICULTURAL SCIENCE IN THEIR CLASSROOM; REGIONAL FARMERS WILL HAVE ACCESS TO NEW MANAGEMENT STRATEGIES FOR ROW RICE PRODUCTION; UNIVERSITY STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN RESEARCH ACTIVITIES AND HAVE ACCESS TO AN INTENSIVE AGRICULTURAL FIELD COURSE THAT INCLUDES SPECIFIC WRITING AND INSTRUMENTATION WORKSHOPS.THROUGH THIS PROJECT WE WILL COLLECT AND PROVIDE DATA ON NITROGEN USE EFFICIENCY, MOISTURE RETENTION AND IRRIGATION WATER USE, AND WEED SUPPRESSION FROM COVER CROP USE IN ROW RICE PRODUCTION. A CROP BUDGET WILL BE DEVELOPED SPECIFICALLY FOR ROW RICE PRODUCTION WITH COVER CROPS AND PROFITABILITY COMPARED TO CONVENTIONAL MANAGEMENT.DURING THIS THREE YEAR PROJECT, WE WILL HAVE DIRECT IMPACT ON TWO LARGE RICE FARMERS, 10 HIGH SCHOOL TEACHERS, 40 COLLEGE STUDENTS, OF WHICH AT LEAST 10 WILL BE FROM REGIONAL MINORITY-SERVING UNIVERSITIES. INDIRECT IMPACT WILL INCLUDE MORE THAN 2000 HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS OVER THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT AND NUMEROUS FARMERS IN THE REGION.
AGRICULTURE AND FOOD LITERACY INITIATIVE AT NORTHWEST MISSOURI STATE
BUILDING CAPACITY FOR CLIMATE CHANGE EDUCATION (CCE) AND EXPANDING RESEARCH OPPORTUNITIES IN RURAL COMMUNITIES IN TN AND KY

SUMMARYPURPOSETHE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CREATE THE EDUCATIONAL INFRASTRUCTURE NEEDED TO PRODUCE THE NEXT GENERATION OF CHANGE AGENTS IN GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY (GFS). WITHIN SEVEN OBJECTIVES, WE WILL CREATE A UNIQUE MASTER'S DEGREE IN GFS, PROVIDE FACULTY DEVELOPMENT IN DISTANCE EDUCATION, PROVIDE INDUSTRY TRAINING, CREATE A STUDY ABROAD LEADERSHIP TRAINING (SALT) ACADEMY, PROVIDE SERVICE LEARNING IN NICARAGUA AND DEVELOP THE SOUTHWEST CONSORTIUM FOR GLOBAL FOOD SECURITY.AUDIENCETHE TARGET OF THE MASTER'S IN GFS WILL INCLUDE MID-CAREER FOOD INDUSTRY PROFESSIONALS AND GRADUATE STUDENTS AT MULTIPLE UNIVERSITIES. FACULTY WILL RECEIVE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT TRAINING AND UNDERGRADUATES WILL PARTICIPATE IN THE SALT ACADEMY AND STUDY ABROAD. PRIMARY AND SECONDARY STUDENTS IN NICARAGUA WILL ENGAGE IN EDUCATIONAL AND LEADERSHIP DEVELOPMENT WITHIN THE SERVICE LEARNING COMPONENT AND THEIR TEACHERS WILL BENEFIT FROM EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS. PRODUCTSSUSTAINABLE PROGRAMS DEVELOPED WILLINCLUDE AT LEAST 10 NEW COURSES AT THE GRADUATE LEVEL, AN ONLINE MASTER'S DEGREE PROGRAM, A STUDY ABROAD LEADERSHIP COURSE AND MULTIPLE INDUSTRY WORKSHOPS. WEB RESOURCES INCLUDE A CLEARINGHOUSE OF GRADUATE STUDENT OPPORTUNITIES IN GFS AND A DIRECTORY OF GFS STAKEHOLDERS IN THE SOUTHWEST CORRIDOR OF THE US.OUTCOME/IMPACTTHIS PROJECT WILL INTEGRATE EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO IMPROVE HUMAN CAPACITY IN GFS. STUDENTS AND FACULTY PARTICIPATING IN THESE EDUCATIONAL INTERVENTIONS WILL GAIN KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF GLOBAL HUNGER AND ITS CAUSES. THE ADDITION OF MULTIPLE STUDENTS GRADUATING WITH ADVANCED TRAINING (EITHER GRADUATE OR UNDERGRADUATE) WILL INCREASE THE HUMAN CAPACITY FOR GFS AND ULTIMATELY HELP CONTINUE TO REDUCE HUNGER ON A GLOBAL SCALE.
